questions.text: Which of the following options is related to Ewing's postulates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Complication resulting from trauma

Ewing's postulates concerns with growth at site following :

A. The tumor must arise exactly at the site injured
B. Definite and substantial trauma must be proved
C. The tumor must be confirmed pathologically
D. The tissue at the site must have been healthy before the trauma;
E. A reasonable interval-neither too long or too short-must elapse between the time of the trauma and the appearance of the tumor
F. Though not one of the Ewing's original postulates, there should be some good scientific reason for ascribing the tumor formation to the injury and this is rarely possible.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: The organ tested in Breslau's second life test is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Stomach and Intestine

Breslau’s second life test- Test for viability of fetus.
  • Live born infant swallows air into stomach if respiration have occurred. The stomach and intestine are dissected and double ligature are applied at both ends.
  • They are kept under water and incision is given.
  • Air bubbles come out then test is positive. False positive can occur if decomposition have occurred.

Breslau's second life test detects changes in stomach and intestine.
  • Principle: Breslau's Second Life Test (Stomach Bowel test) It assumes that a live born child would respire and therefore would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. Thus detecting the presence of air in stomach and intestine (positive test) proves live birth (even in absence of positive hydrostatic lung test if there had been some obstruction in respiratory passage).
  • However, negative test (absence of air in stomach and bowel) does not always mean still-birth since air does not necessarily enter stomach in adequate amounts during act of breathing. Procedure: The stomach and intestine are removed separately after tying double ligature at each end, place them both in water.
  • They float in water if respiration has taken place, otherwise they will sink. No medicolegal value: Because air may be swallowed by child in attempting to free the air passage of fluid obstruction in case of still-birth. It is useless in putrefaction.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 413.

questions.text: The following patient was brought in for an autopsy. What is cause of discolouration in in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hematoma formation
 
  • Image given is mostly suggestive of hematoma formation. 
  • If the bleeding is small and thin-layered, it is called haemorrhage. If it is large and space- occupying, it is called haematoma.
  • The application of a moderate force to the head may cause a severe intracranial haemorrhage, while a greater force may not produce haemorrhage. Injuries to the meninges may cause extradural, subdural or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 242.

questions.text:
Police discovered and brought a deceased male foetus that had been abandoned for autopsy. "The head to feet length is
63 cm, eyes are open, pupillary membrane is absent, Crown Rump Length is 23 cm, testes are at the superficial inguinal ring, and the weight of the foetus is 1000 gm," was the report. What is the fetus's approximate age?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. 7 months

Hess’ rule can be used to calculate the age of the fetus:


Crown-Rump length, CRL=â…”*CHL (Crown Heel length)

Hence, CHL = 3/2 CRL

So, Here CHL = 3/2 x 23 = 34.5 = 35 cm approx.

Now Applying Hess's rule, 

Age = 35/5 = 7 months

Also, the pupillary membrane also disappears at 7 months.

The testes reach the level of superficial inguinal at 7 months as well.

Hence, the age of the fetus is 7 months.
 

Reference: Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Page No 438.

questions.text: According to Gustafson's method, what is the most significant indicator of age determination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Root transparency
 
  • Dentin becomes less visible with age, as mineral deposits fill the wide dentin tubules which become smaller and less translucent.
  • This process of gradual mineralization is the most dependable way of determining a person's age. After around 30 years of age, the dentin becomes transparent due to mineralization and osteoporosis.
  • This makes Root transparency the single most important indicator for Gustafson method of age analysis.
  • Transparency of root occurs from below upwards in lower jaw and from above downwards in upper jaw. It is the most reliable of all criteria.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 69.

questions.text: What is Locard known for?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Theory of Exchange 'Locard's Exchange Principle' 

When any two objects come into contact, there is always a transfer of material from each object on the other. Trace from the scene may be carried away on the person or tool of the criminal, and at the same time, traces from all or any of these may be left at the scene.

It is actual evidence, and its presence is absolute proof of the crime. The evidence of eyewitnesses may be wrong as a result of their partisanship, faulty memory, or defective observation. Physical evidence cannot be wrong and completely absent. Only its interpretation can be wrong. Only human failure to find it, study and understand it, can diminish its value.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 443.

questions.text:
In relation to fingerprint alterations, match the following:
(a) Ridge atrophy (i) Dermatitis
(b) Permanent loss of fingerprints (ii) Acromegaly
(c) Ridge alteration (iii) Radiation
(d) Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy (iv) Scleroderma
(e) Increased distance between ridges (v) Coeliac disease
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-v, e-ii
 
  • Fingerprints are papillary ridges on fingers which are unique. Fingerprints are the best method for criminal identification as it is not even identical in identical twins (Quetlet Rule).
  • Permanent loss of fingerprints occur in leprosy, electorcution (charring) and radiation. Ridge atrophy is seen in Coeliac disease, dermatitis.
  • Ridge alteration is seen in acanthosis nigricans scleroderma, eczema. Increased space between ridges is noted in acromegaly.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 84.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option.
 A. Medial end of clavicle 1. 21-25yrs 
B. Cristal scapula 2. 50yrs
C. Sacrum 3. 25yrs
D. Lambdoid suture 4. 30-45yrs
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

  • During the sixth week of fetal development, two primary centres appear in the shaft and quickly join with one another. The secondary centre arises between the ages of 15 and 20 years old, and by the age of 25, the sternal end, ossifies and joins with the shaft. 
  • Sacrum- It typically consists of five separate vertebrae in children, which start to fuse between the ages of 16 and 18 and are usually fully fused into a single bone by the time the kid reaches the age of 26. 
  • Lambdoid suture- starts at 25-30 yr.
  • Cristal scapula - 50 years

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who was allegedly kidnapped insists that she is not a juvenile and left her home with the person on her own accord when questioned. Her age was determined by the court. The pelvic, wrist, and bilateral elbow X-rays are provided below. What age do you think she is, based on these?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. 21-22 years
 
  • The age in the images can be determined by the level of ossification of the elbow.
  • In the first, all the ossification centers have fused together, so this subject must be around 16 years or older.
  • In the second, the lower end of the radius and ulna have fused, meaning their age must be at least 18 years.
  • The third image has an ossification of the ischial tuberosity, indicating a subject likely between 20 and 22 years old age. Therefore, the accurate age range would be 21 to 22 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 80.

questions.text: Which organ is best or most favoured for DNA extraction during autopsy:?
questions.solution:
The organ most favored for DNA extraction during an autopsy is the 1. Liver.

The liver is often chosen because it is generally larger and contains a higher quantity of DNA compared to other organs, making it a reliable source for genetic analysis.

 
  • In autopsy, deep muscle tissue samples are most suitable as they are most resistant to decomposition.
  • The next choice is cardiac muscle. Other autopsy samples for DNA are teeth (preferably molar teeth), hair with roots, blood.

Reference: Atmadja DS, Tatsuno Y, Ueno Y, Nishimura A. The effect of extraction methods. The kind of organ samples and the examination delay on the DNA yields and typing. Kobe J Med Sci. 1995 Dec;41(6):197-211. PMID: 8869006.

questions.text: The skull's minimum anterior-posterior diameter is in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3 Brachycephaly 
 
  • Brachycephaly is a condition in which the skull is relatively short and wide, with a cephalic index (ratio of the maximum width of the skull to its maximum length) of over 80%.
  • This means that the minimum anterior-posterior diameter of the skull is relatively short compared to the maximum width.
  • The opposite of brachycephaly is dolichocephaly, in which the skull is relatively long and narrow, with a cephalic index of less than 75%. Mesaticephalic skulls have a cephalic index between 75% and 80%.
  • Trigonocephaly is a condition in which the skull has a triangular shape due to premature closure of the metopic suture.
Cephalic index is maximum transverse breadth of skull divided by maximum anterio-posterior length of skull multiplied by 100.
Based on CI, 3 types of skull-
1. Dolicho-cephalic (Long headed)- 70 to 74.9, Negroid
2. Mesati-cephalic (Medium headed)- 75 to 79.9, Caucasians, Chinese, Indians
3. Brachy-cephalic (Short headed)- 80 to 84.9, Mongoloids

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 56.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that employs the method of removing cervical, thoracic and abdominal organs from tongue to prostate as a single mass is:
questions.solution:
The “en masse” method of removal of internal organs was originally described by Letulle.

  • Most internal organs are removed in one full swoop.
  • It is a rapid technique for removing the organs from the body although the ensuing dissection is the lengthiest.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 109.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that is done to limit the spread of infection in HIV patients:
questions.solution:
The in-situ method of dissection, developed by Rokitansky is the method of choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases such as HIV, COVID, Hep B since the organs are dissected in situ with little actual evisceration being performed prior to dissection, avoiding unnecessary exposure to body fluids in the process of evisceration which may transmit the disease.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 109.

questions.text: The temperature of a dead body was found to be 39°C. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
In this case, the temperature of the dead body is found to be raised.

  • This phenomenon is termed postmortem caloricity in which instead of cooling, the temperature of the dead body remains high for approximately the initial 2 hours.
  • Excessive bacterial activity which may occur in septicemia, cholera and other fevers is one of the causes of postmortem caloricity.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 155.

questions.text: Which among the following is least used in identification of dead body?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Nail is least used in identification of dead body.

Reference: Simpson's Forensic Medicine, 12th Edition, Page No: 53.

questions.text: During a police investigation, the police found some bones in the open space. Which of the following tests can be used to differentiate between human and animal bones?
questions.solution:
The Precipitin test is a serological test used in forensic science to distinguish human from animal bones or blood.

Key points:

  • Principle:

    • Antiserum is produced by injecting human proteins into an animal (e.g., rabbit).

    • When the unknown bone or blood sample is added, precipitation occurs if it contains human proteins.

  • Other tests:

    • Barberio test: Not used for species differentiation (used for forensic blood identification historically)

    • Takayama test & Teichmann test: Detect presence of hemoglobin in blood, used to confirm blood, not species

questions.text: During an autopsy, what is commonly used to preserve blood?
questions.solution:
During autopsy, blood preservation is important for toxicology and biochemical analysis.

  • Sodium fluoride (NaF) is commonly added to blood samples to inhibit glycolysis, preserving glucose and other analytes. 

  • Formalin: Fixative for tissues, not for blood biochemistry.

  • Rectified spirit (ethanol): Used for tissue dehydration, not routine blood preservation.

  • NaCl (normal saline): Isotonic solution; does not prevent glycolysis or preserve analytes.

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected organ in an air blast due to shockwave?
questions.solution:
In air blast injuries (primary blast injuries caused by a shockwave), the most commonly affected organ is the lung.

  • The lungs are air-filled and relatively compressible, making them susceptible to:

    • Pulmonary contusions

    • Hemorrhage

    • Pneumothorax or blast lung

  • Other organs can be affected, but air-filled organs are most vulnerable.

Other options — brief:
2. Kidney: Solid organ; less affected by primary blast wave.
3. Spleen: Can be injured in blunt trauma, but not the most common in shockwave.
4. Intestine: Can be affected, but less commonly than lungs; more vulnerable to secondary blast injuries (shrapnel).

choices.text: Stained area folded and preserved in plastic bag
Dry over spirit lamp and preserve it
Stained area folded and preserved in paper bag

questions.text: What is the best method to preserve a blood-stained handkerchief recovered from a crime scene?
questions.solution:
To preserve blood-stained items, such as a handkerchief, follow these guidelines:

Folding and Storing: The stained handkerchief should be folded and placed in a paper bag to protect it during storage.

Drying: Allow the stained item to air dry at room temperature without applying heat, as heat can degrade the stain.

Avoiding Decomposition: It's crucial to dry the stained clothing adequately; failure to do so may lead to putrefaction, complicating the determination of whether the blood is of human or animal origin.

Labeling: Label the stained object with your initials and the date. If labeling is impractical, attach a tag or another identifier to ensure proper identification.

Container Considerations: Avoid using airtight containers, as trapped moisture can foster bacterial growth and damage the stains.

Individual Wrapping: Wrap each garment individually to prevent contact between different stains, ensuring that no two stains touch.

Paper Barriers: It is advisable to place a clean sheet of paper between each stain to prevent cross-contamination.

Forensic Examination: All types of stains should be sent to the State Forensic Science Laboratory for examination.

questions.text: Which of the following cavities is opened first in case of fetal autopsy?
questions.solution:
• The correct order of conducting fetal autopsy is Cranium > Abdomen > Thorax.
  • Abdomen is opened before thorax to note highest point of diaphragm.
  • Cavities that contain trace evidence are opened first compared to cavities that contain maximum evidence are opened last to prevent artefacts.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33rd Edition, Page No 438-440.

choices.text: Cadaveric spasm is observed only in specific groups of muscles
Greenish discoloration in the right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition
Adipocere is found in bodies recovered from water sources
In drowning cases, postmortem hypostasis is only seen in the lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following statements about postmortem changes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
In drowning cases, if the water is still, post-mortem hypostasis affects the head, chest, and limbs. This occurs because the chest and abdomen float higher due to the presence of lung and abdominal gases. However, in drowning incidents in fast-flowing water, postmortem staining may be absent since the body's position continuously changes.

Postmortem hypostasis (also known as postmortem staining, postmortemlividity, livor mortis, or suggilation) refers to the bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. This early postmortem change results from blood pooling in the dependent areas due to gravity.


 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 152,155-158,163,165,171 .

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
In chronic starvation, all of the following changes occur except hyperthermia; instead, hypothermia is observed.

The physiological changes associated with chronic starvation include a loss of well-being, feelings of hunger, rapid weight loss, increased fatigue, lethargy, cachexia, anemia, hypotension, hypothermia, and polyuria. Edema in the lower limbs can occur due to hypoproteinemia, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

Laboratory findings show decreased levels of blood sugar, cholesterol, protein, and chloride, while non-protein nitrogen, urea, plasma free acids, and ketone bodies are elevated.

Death in chronic starvation typically results from exhaustion, brown atrophy of the heart, and intercurrent infections. Additionally, hypothermia and dehydration may contribute to mortality.

A postmortem examination of the internal organs reveals:
  • Atrophied and darker muscles
  • Brown atrophy of the heart
  • Atrophy of the stomach and intestines
  • Shrunken spleen
  • Atrophied kidneys
  • Decreased blood volume, indicative of anemia
  • The gallbladder may also appear distended with bile.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to detect blood stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is not utilized for detecting blood stains; rather, it is employed to identify the presence of semen.

This test detects spermine picrate, a substance found in prostatic secretions. To perform the test, a drop of the suspected spermatic fluid is placed on a glass slide and mixed with a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Upon microscopic examination, the presence of needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals confirms the presence of semen.



Other options:

  • Takayama’s test → Microcrystal confirmatory test for blood (hemochromogen crystals).

  • Teichmann’s test → Microcrystal confirmatory test for blood (hemin crystals).

  • Spectroscopy → Used to detect hemoglobin derivatives (oxyHb, deoxyHb, carboxyHb, metHb).

questions.text: In which poisoning is cherry red hypostasis seen on postmortem examination?
questions.solution:
Cherry red hypostasis observed during postmortem examination is indicative of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.



Postmortem Findings in CO Poisoning:
Cherry Red Discoloration: The skin, mucosa, blood, tissues, and internal organs exhibit a bright cherry red color.
Pulmonary Congestion: The lungs show congestion, often accompanied by pink fluid blood.
Hemorrhages: Commonly noted pleural and pericardial hemorrhages.
Bilateral Symmetrical Necrosis: There is characteristic necrosis and cavitation observed in the basal ganglia, particularly in the globus pallidus and putamen, which is associated with delayed deaths.
Brain Hemorrhages: Punctiform and ring-shaped hemorrhages may be present in the white matter of the brain.
These findings are critical for forensic analysis in cases of suspected carbon monoxide poisoning.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
A postmortem examination revealing contraction of the hands along with the absence of primary relaxation indicates the presence of cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm, also known as instantaneous rigor, is a phenomenon characterized by the immediate and sustained contraction of specific muscle groups at the time of death. This contraction persists until molecular death occurs, and there is no initial stage of primary relaxation.

This phenomenon is most frequently observed in voluntary muscles, particularly the hands. It often occurs in cases where death is associated with significant emotional disturbances, such as excitement, fear, severe pain, or exhaustion at the time of death.

Cadaveric spasm is considered an antemortem phenomenon, indicating the manner of death rather than the time since death.

questions.text: Following the recovery of a beheaded skull bone by the police, the relatives of a missing person want to confirm his identity. Which of the following techniques can be used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person?
questions.solution:
The method employed to identify an individual using a beheaded skull and a photograph of the person is known as superimposition. This technique involves overlaying the photograph onto the skull to assess whether they correspond.

Several anatomical landmarks can be utilized for comparison, including:

Eyes
Nasion (the bridge of the nose)
Prosthion (the point on the maxilla)
Zygomas (cheekbones)
Lower border of the nose
Supraorbital ridges (brow ridges)
Lower border of the zygomas
Angle of the jaw
External auditory meatus (ear canal)
Teeth
Lower border of the upper jaw
These reference points help in determining if the skull belongs to the individual in the photograph.

 

Other options:

  • Anthropometry → body measurements, used in living persons, not applicable to skull-photograph matching.

  • DNA fingerprinting → gold standard for identity confirmation, but requires soft tissue/blood/bone marrow, not just external skull matching.

  • Cheiloscopy → lip print analysis, not useful if only a skull is available.

questions.text: An unidentified body was found weeks after a missing report in a nearby lake. Which of the following methods can be used to identify the body weeks after death?
questions.solution: DNA profiling, also known as genetic fingerprinting, is a forensic method used to identify individuals based on their unique genetic makeup, it is precise and has high specificity. While decomposition can damage biological tissues, DNA can often be recovered from highly decomposed bodies and compared with reference samples from relatives. Ref: Saad R. Discovery, development, and current applications of DNA identity testing. Proc (Bayl Univ Med Cent). 2005;18(2):130-133. doi:10.1080/08998280.2005.11928051

questions.text: A post-mortem cooling graph is plotted. | What ts the ideal shape of this graph?
questions.solution:
The post-mortem cooling (algor mortis) curve represents the decline of body temperature after death.

  • The graph of body temperature vs. time ideally shows an S-shaped curve:

    • Initial phase: Slow temperature drop immediately after death (lag phase).

    • Middle phase: Faster, almost linear cooling (log phase).

    • Final phase: Approaches ambient temperature, rate slows down (plateau).

  • Parabolic, hyperbolic, and sigmoid are not typical representations of the post-mortem cooling process.

Thus, the ideal post-mortem cooling graph is S-shaped.



Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 154-156,158,162,164-166

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to GOLD's criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
The GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria classify COPD severity based on post-bronchodilator FEV1 as a percentage of predicted and the FEV1/FVC ratio:

  • Airflow obstruction: FEV1/FVC < 0.7

  • Severity:

    • Mild (GOLD 1): FEV1 ≥ 80%

    • Moderate (GOLD 2): FEV1 50–79%

    • Severe (GOLD 3): FEV1 30–49%

    • Very severe (GOLD 4): FEV1 < 30%

Since this patient has moderate COPD, the FEV1/FVC ratio is less than 0.7 (obstruction) and FEV1 is between 50–80% of predicted.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute dyspnea and chest pain, and is bedridden, which are risk factors for pulmonary embolism (PE).

  • D-dimer is a screening test for thromboembolic events. It is highly sensitive but not specific. A negative D-dimer can effectively rule out PE in low-to-moderate risk patients.

Other options:

  • MR Angiogram: Not routinely used for screening; mainly for diagnosis if CT pulmonary angiography is contraindicated.

  • Echocardiography: Can detect right heart strain or indirect signs of PE, but not definitive for diagnosis.

  • Coagulogram: Assesses coagulation status but does not identify thromboembolism.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1991
Medicine-Forensic identity

questions.text: A 10-year-old child will have _?
questions.solution:
• By 10 years of age, the child is in the mixed dentition stage.

  • Permanent teeth erupted by this age: All first permanent molars (4), central and lateral incisors (8), totaling 12–16 permanent teeth depending on individual variation.

  • Remaining temporary (deciduous) teeth: Usually 8 (canines and second molars that haven’t been replaced yet).

So, the most accepted number is 16 permanent and 8 temporary teeth at 10 years


Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 69

questions.text: What is the killing method used in Harakiri?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Stab in abdomen

Harakiri or Seppuku is an unique and an unusual type of ceremonial suicide (practiced by Samurai warriors in Japan) in which a seated victim inflicts a single large abdominal stab wound causing evisceration of abdominal organs.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No193.

Marshall's triad is diagnostic of explosive injury. Marshall's triad includes bruises, abrasions & puncture lacerations and not the fracture.

questions.text: What is the term for the segmentation of blood in a blood artery after death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Kevorkian sign

The Kevorkian sign is segmentation of blood in the artery after death. Within minutes of death and for the next hour or so, the blood columns in the retinal vessels begin to segment or fragment (also known as trucking or shunting) (Kevorkian sign).



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 145.

questions.text: Which of the following injuries is related with rat holes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Bullet injury

Rat hole is associated with bullet injury (by Mid/Near range shotgun shot) fired from a distance of 2m/7ft. It is nothing but an irregular entry wound with ragged margins, also called as Cookie Cutter appearance. There can be associated Satellite perforations at the margins of main defect.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 207.

choices.text: Gutter fracture skull with cervical spine injury
Pond fracture skull with cervical spine injury
Depressed fracture skull with cervical spine injury

questions.text: A man fell 35 feet from a height. According to eyewitnesses, he landed on his feet. Which of the following injuries could occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Ring fracture of foramen magnum with lumbar spine injury

* Ring or Foramen Fractures:
  • Fissured fractures known as Ring or Foramen fractures ring the skull in such a way that the anterior third is split where it meets the middle and posterior thirds.
  • However, the phrase is typically used to refer to a fracture that separates the skull from the spine and runs 3 to 5 cm outside the foramen magnum at the back and sides of the skull. It also passes forward through the middle ears and roof of the nose.
  • They are uncommon and result from falls that land on the feet or buttocks.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: Following a collision, two bodies are discovered outside the vehicle. The doctor performing the autopsy would be able to differentiate and determine who was the driver and who was passenger based on all the below parameters EXCEPT _________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Sparrow footmarks.
 
  • Sparrow footmarks occur in both driver as well as passenger. It does not differentiate between driver and passenger.
  • Steering wheel imprint (option 2) and seat belt abrasion over right shoulder (option 4) will occur primarily in the driver. Hence, presence of steering wheel impact and abrasion over right shoulder would help in identification of driver.
  • Whiplash injury (option 1) can occur in both front seat occupant and driver but is more common in front seat occupant because the driver stabilizes his neck just before impact (due to early perception of impact) - hence even whiplash injury can help in differentiation. 
  • When injury occurs, the glass broke and shatters into small cubes. These glass cubes may cause “V” shaped lacerations. These are called as dicing injuries or sparrow-foot lacerations. They would present equally in both driver and passenger and hence we would not be able to differentiate based on them.


Fig: Wind screen impact

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 207.

choices.text: Coagulation necrosis occurs at the site of burn

questions.text: After a quarrel, a husband sprays sulfuric acid on his wife, who then visits the emergency room for supportive care. All of the following are true regarding chemical burns, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Absence of singeing of hairs
 
  • Sulfuric acid is a strong acid that can cause significant thermal injury in addition to chemical burns.
  • When sulfuric acid comes into contact with skin, it can generate heat due to its exothermic reaction, potentially causing singeing of hairs.
  • Therefore, singeing of hairs may indeed be present in such burns.
  • The hydroxyl ion produces a saponification of fat, soluble alkaline proteinases, cellular dehydration and an exothermic reaction. The ion passes from molecule to molecule, denaturing each in burn, and burrows deeply, producing soft gelatillous, friable eschars (liquefaction necrosis).

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 499.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on an accidental death case. It revealed two linear fractures in the petrous portion of the temporal bone. Which of the following rules describes the fracture sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Puppe’s rule
 
  • Puppe's rule states that when two or more fracture lines of the skull produced by blunt forces intersect, it is possible to reconstruct the sequence of injuries.
  • Puppe's rule tells that an extending fracture line will cease if it meets a preexisting fracture or suture line.


Fig: Piece of glass showing two impacts

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 214.

questions.text: Which of the following results is not related to blast injury?

Bomb explosion is indicated by the "TRIAD" of bruises, abrasions, puncture lacerations, and tattooing on the body. This is referred to as the Marshall Triad.

Kraissl’s line are anatomical lines of maximum skin tension. They are oriented perpendicular to the action of the underlying muscles.

questions.text: What is bullet fingerprinting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Secondary markings

Bullet fingerprinting is the presence of secondary markings on the bullet, useful to identify one specific gun to the exclusion of all others.
 
  • The bullet's primary and secondary markings aid in identifying the weapon.
  • When compared to markings on a bullet that was test-fired from the suspected gun, secondary marks that are caused by an elevation or depression on the inner surface of the barrel of the gun will tell specifically about the particular gun that has been used.
  • Primary markings on the surface of the bullet provide information about the "make" or type of the gun used.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem finding in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Suggillation
 
  • The image is suggestive of post-mortem hypostasis, which is also known as suggillation.
  • Postmortem hypostasis is the bluish-purple or purplish red coloring (caused by deoxyhemoglobin) that develops in the dependent parts of the body after death in the dermis's most superficial layers, Also known as livor mortis, suggillation, vibices, postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, and darkening of death.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 155.

questions.text: Which fracture is shown in the photograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Hinge

The fracture in the given image is hinge fracture, which is also known as motorcyclist fracture.
 
  • The most common fatal injury to motorcyclists is due to second impact with the ground.
  • A very severe blow to one side of the head results in fractures across the pituitary fossa's middle fossa's floor.
  • At autopsy, the so-called "motorcyclist fracture" can be detected, which is the base of the skull split into two pieces that move independently of one another like hinges.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 281.

The lesion in the given image is abrasion.

questions.text: A patient committed suicide by shooting a bullet into his right temple. On post-mortem examination, the skull was burst open. There was charring and cherry red discoloration along the track of bullet and the weapon was firmly clasped in the right hand of deceased. The bullet was fired from what distance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Contact Shot
 
  • A contact shot is characterized  by charring and cherry red coloration of the track of the bullet as the discharge of the muzzle, comprising flame, powder grains, metallic particles, and hot gases, is blasted into the track.
  • This causes carboxyhemoglobin formation that results in pink coloration of the track. As well, the high pressure of the gases injected into the track from the contact shot can result in bursting of the skull.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 221.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, jaw, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, facial muscle upper limb, thorax
Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: What is the order of development of rigor mortis according to Nysten’s rule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
 
  • According to Nysten's rule, order of development of rigor mortis is orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb.
  • The muscles of the body, including voluntary and involuntary, are affected in order of emergence of rigor (Nysten's rule).
  • Not all muscles experience it at the same time. It starts in the involuntary muscles, and within an hour, the myocardium becomes hard.
  • It starts in the muscles of the eyelids, neck, and lower jaw, moves up to the muscles of the face, moves down to the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, belly, and lower limbs, and ends up in the muscles of the fingers and toes.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 161.

questions.text:
In a burglarized room, a middle-aged woman was discovered laying in a bloody pool. Upon forensic inspection, a 2 cm by 2 cm entry wound was found on the
left temporal region, which had tattooing and blackening all around it. The right temporal area also has an exit wound with beveling. Two gunshot fragments were
discovered inside the brain parenchyma upon closer inspection. Which of the following could be applied to establish the weapon's firing range?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Hair
 
  • Hair can be used to assess the distance of firing.
  • The presence of burning or singeing (due to flame), blacking (due to smoke), and tattooing are needed findings to compute range (due to gun powder).
  • The tattooing that was discovered is up to intermediate level. Hair should be examined for the presence of any singeing or smoke deposits to determine whether the the gun was discharged from close range.
  • same can be done with clothing, but since the harm in this case is to the skull, hair is a preferable choice.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 224.

questions.text: What kind of damage is present in the left anterior chest region of the patient in the following?
questions.solution:
Laceration is a disruption of the continuity of tissue caused by a blunt force. Here the full thickness of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, muscle and/ or the internal organs can get involved.

In laceration margins are not smooth and tissue bridges present whereas in incised wound margins are smooth and tissue margins are absent.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 189.

questions.text: What does this image show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Pugilistic attitude

The post-mortem, "boxer like" body posture of flexed elbows and knees and clenched fists, caused by the shrinkage of body tissue and muscles due to dehydration and coagulation of proteins caused by high temperature resulting in stiffening and shortening of muscles. It can be caused in both ante-mortem and post-mortem burns.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 322.

questions.text: What does Ploucquet’s test include while assessing infant deaths?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Change in partial weight of lungs

Ploucquet's test helps to demonstrate establishment of respiration in fetus (to ascertain viability of fetus).
The ratio of the weight of lungs to weight of whole body gets reduced to half as compared to ratio before respiration.
Before respiration- Lungs to body ratio=1:70
After respiration- Lungs to body ratio=1:35

Hydrostatic test uses change in specific gravity of lungs-
Before respiration- 1040 to 1050
After respiration- 940 (due to increase in volume of lungs)

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 439.

questions.text: Pick the option which is known as 'signature fracture' in medico-legal injury.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. Depressed fracture
 
  • Depressed Fracture of skull vault is also known as 'Fracture-ala signature' or 'Signature fracture'.
  • It is caused by a heavy weapon with small striking surface like a hammer.
  • Its shape may indicate the type of weapon with which it is produced, hence the name. 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: In a case of mortality from a gunshot damage caused by surgical modifications, it is challenging to assess and distinguish between the entry wound and exit wound. This occurrence is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Kennedy phenomenon 

Kennedy Phenomenon states that Surgical alteration or suturing of gunshot wounds creates problems in evaluation of the wound, whether it's an entrance or an exit wound. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: Where are primary impact injuries most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Legs

Impact injury is the damage caused by the collision of a body with a moving or stationary object.
The best example is collision of a person walking on the road with a moving car.
Primary impact injury is caused by initial strike, i.e., the first part of the vehicle that strikes the victim (usually legs). Secondary impact injuries are injuries produced due to an impact between the body part and the vehicle for the second time. Secondary injuries are injuries not by the car but due to the person falling down on the road i.e., ground impact injury.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Which of the following bullets leaves a mark visible enough for someone to perceive it:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Tracer bullet.

Tracer bullets leave a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the strike of shot can be observed. They enable the shooter to make aiming corrections.

* Other types of bullets:
  • Tandem bullet: Two bullets are ejected one after giving a piggy back effect. This may occur due to the defect in weapon.
  • Dum Dum bullet: It has a chiselled-out tip that fragments extensively on impact.
  • Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorus which ignites on hitting the target.
  • Ricochet bullet: The bullet first strikes an intermediate object, gets reflected in a way that it changes direction and then strikes the target.
  • Yawning bullet: Moves in an irregular way and produces a keyhole type of entry wound.
  • Tumbling bullet: Rotates a whole 360 degree i.e., end on end before hitting the target 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 215.

questions.solution:

Lightning causes injury by the following mechanisms:
Direct effect of a very high voltage current results into sudden cardiac arrest Burning due to super-heated air The atmospheric gasses in the path of lightening become heated and cause explosive expansion of air Compression effect due to air movement in its return wave (not in front) produces the changes.

questions.text: Which organ begins to putrefy first?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Brain.

Amongst the given options, the first organ to putrefy is Brain and the last to putrefy is Prostate.
Putrefaction is the disintegration by bacterial enzymes Most important – Clostridium Welchii Time taken for putrefaction to begin: 12-18 hours in summer 2-3 days in winter Mechanism: Colliquative liquefaction of tissues Poisons that delay putrefaction: Strychnine, Metals, Carbolic acid Order of putrefaction from first to last: Larynx and Trachea Stomach and intestine Lungs and liver Brain Heart Kidney Prostate and Uterus Muscles, tendons Skin Bones.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: What does a mummified body smell like?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Odorless.
 
  • When a dead body is exposed to dry, hot climate with free flow of air, it results in dryness and dehydration. This causes shrinking in such a way that 70% of body weight is lost which leads to mummification.
  • Time taken: 3-12 months
  • The process is odourless.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 172.

questions.text: A swollen face was observed in a patient with tongue swelling, and the results are displayed in the image. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Putrefaction
 
  • Putrefaction is the process by which complex organic body tissue breaks down into simpler inorganic compounds or elements due to the action of saprophytic microorganisms or due to autolysis (without bacterial involvement).
  • The first external sign of putrefaction is a greenish discoloration in the right iliac fossa. Internally, the first site of discoloration is the aortic intima and then the underside of the liver.
  • Marbling, a linear branching pattern on the skin, is most commonly noted on the shoulder, root of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest and neck region.
  • Tongue and other organ protrusion occurs due to gas accumulation and organ enlargement.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: Following a car accident, a patient is taken to the emergency department. A 3x1 cm lacerated bone-deep wound is seen over the scalp. Which of the following best describes the proper mechanism of this lacerated wound?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history, the lacerated wound would most likely be a split laceration.

Laceration is defined as the splitting of epidermis/dermis/subcutaneous tissue caused by a heavy blunt force.

Types of laceration—

+Stretch laceration : Due to a tangential force on skin. Eg : Being run over by a vehicle.

+Shearing Laceration : Skin tissue gets avulsed and remains attached by a small margin of tissue (flaying).

Eg : Being run over by a vehicle at an acute angle.

+Cut Laceration : Spindle shaped gaping wound also known as chop/slash wound. 

+Split Laceration, also known as incision looking laceration on bony prominences.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 190.

questions.text: Two friends get into a fight after consuming alcohol. One of them pushes the other to the floor and covers his face, stopping him from breathing while sitting on his chest. What's this known as?
questions.solution:
Based on the history given the mechanism of death here is burking. The person has died due to asphyxia by suffocation. It is a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
A person lies on the chest of the victim, preventing breathing and also covers the nose and mouth (face) with his hands.

History- This method of killing was developed by William Burk and William Hare who used to intoxicate homeless people kill them by Burking and used to sell their bodies to an Anatomy Professor. 


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 364.

  • Adipocere: Adipocere appears chalky and greasy, and is light grey in color.
  • Postmortem Hypostasis: Postmortem hypostasis appears as a purplish-red discoloration of the skin and is usually found on the parts of the body that have come in contact with the ground.
  • Mummification: Mummification is a process of natural desiccation where the skin of the body is dried out and tightens on the body, giving it a leathery appearance.

questions.text: Which type of laceration exhibits flaying?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Avulsion
 
  • Flaying is seen in avulsion.
  • An avulsion is a forcible tearing off of skin or another part of the body, such as an ear or a finger. Any time layers of skin have been torn off to expose muscles, tendons and tissue, it is called an avulsion.

questions.text: A woman assaulted by a neighbour was brought to you in the emergency department with a fracture of the middle tooth. The injury was extended medially to the mouth where there was also a contusion to the bilateral leg. What in the nature of the injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Grievous injury

The nature of injury is grievous hurt.
Because Sixth clause of Sec 320 IPC(Grievous hurt) constitutes fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth as grievous hurt.
The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous"-
First.—Emasculation.
Secondly.—Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
Thirdly.—Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
Fourthly.—Privation of any member or joint.
Fifthly.—Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint.
Sixthly.—Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
Seventhly.—Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
Eighthly.—Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: The following is not a feature of superficial second-degree burns:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Heal with scarring
  • Superficial second-degree burns, also known as partial-thickness burns, involve the epidermis and the upper dermis layer of the skin.
  • These types of burns are characterized by redness, pain, and the presence of blisters.
  • However, they do not typically result in scarring as the damage is limited to the top layers of the skin, and the skin is able to regenerate new cells to replace the damaged ones.
  • The healing process of superficial second-degree burns typically takes around 2-3 weeks, and the skin may peel or itch during this time.
  • However, scarring is not a common outcome of this type of burn unless the burn is very deep or becomes infected. In such cases, the burn may progress to a full-thickness burn, which can result in scarring.
  • Therefore, option 3 is the correct answer as healing with scarring is not a typical feature of superficial second-degree burns.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 321.

  • In cases of multiple gunshot wounds of the skull, determination of the sequence in which the wounds took place is done by Puppe’s rule.
  • Puppe's rule was actually developed by Madea in relation to bullet injuries, but it is applicable to any multiple blunt forces causing fracture.
  • The fractures from 1st injury develop normally, while those caused by subsequent injury are stopped where they intersect with the existent fracture lines.
  • This pattern of radical fracture lines allows the determination of sequence of gun shots.

questions.text: Fencing posture is caused by:

  • Contraction of paraspinal muscles often causes a marked opisthotonus, in an attitude commonly adopted by boxers. 
  • This stiffening is due to the coagulation of proteins of the muscles and dehydration which cause contraction. The flexor muscles being bulkier than extensors contract more due to which joints of all limbs are flexed.
  • It occurs whether the person was alive or dead at the time of burning

questions.text: Identify the mechanical injury shown in the picture.
questions.solution:
• Hesitation wounds, also known as hesitation marks, are shallow cuts or scratches that are often seen in cases of self-harm or attempted suicide. Hesitation wounds are so named because they are thought to be the result of hesitation or uncertainty on the part of the individual, who may be unsure about whether or not they want to carry out their suicidal or self-harming impulses.
  • They are superficial cuts or scratches on the skin that are typically smaller and less severe than the final self-inflicted wound. They are often irregular in shape and may appear shallow or jagged. Hesitation wounds are usually located near the intended site of the final wound, such as on the wrists or arms, and may be seen as an indicator of hesitation or ambivalence on the part of the individual.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 181,185,189,194 .

questions.text: Cadaveric Spasm is not seen in?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm (instantaneous rigor) occurs due to extreme stress, fear, or excitement before death and is commonly associated with violent deaths, especially those involving strong emotions or struggle. It is typically observed in cases such as:

  • Drowning deaths – The victim may grasp weeds or other objects in the water.
  • Traumatic asphyxia – Cases involving intense struggle before death can show cadaveric spasm.
  • Fear or excitement – Strong emotional distress can trigger it.

However, brain injury typically causes rapid unconsciousness or death without significant voluntary muscle contraction, making cadaveric spasm unlikely.

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The image of burns with blisters and surrounding hyperemia suggests a diagnosis of antemortem burns.

In antemortem burns, a zone of hyperemia (a line of redness) is present at the edge of the burn area. This hyperemia, which varies in width, is due to tissue edema and capillary dilation, merging with the burn‘s edge. It affects the full thickness of the skin and persists even after death. If the entire body is burned, this line of redness will be absent.

Antemortem blisters appear as raised domes containing serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. The base of these blisters shows reddening and swollen papillae. In cases of antemortem burns, the skin adjacent to the burn area exhibits increased enzyme activity. This includes elevated levels of sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers, as well as increases in ATP esterases, aminopeptidases, and both acid and alkaline phosphatases. These changes, along with marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, are known as vital reactions and are characteristic of antemortem burns.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 326,327,588,589 .

questions.text: In cases of firearm-related death where the entry wound exhibits only an abrasion collar, the range of the firearm is:
questions.solution:
When the entry wound displays only an abrasion collar, it indicates that the firearm was discharged from a distant range.

To determine the firing range, the following parameters are considered:

The size and shape of the entry wound

Blast effects, including muzzle end imprint and edge eversion

Blackening, tattooing, singeing of hair, abrasion collar, and grease collar

Hair should be preserved for analysis, as it can reveal carbonization or desiccation at close range. Additionally, lead deposition around the wound can help assess the firing range

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 224 .

questions.text: In a case of alcohol abuse, which of the following preservatives is used to preserve blood during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride (NaF) (10 mg/ml) and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) can be used to preserve blood during an autopsy.
Sodium Fluoride (NaF) inhibits glycolysis by preventing the breakdown of glucose, which could alter the blood alcohol content.
It also has antimicrobial properties to prevent the growth of bacteria and fungi and potassium oxalate acts as an anticoagulant to
prevent blood clotting and helps analyse the sample. Ref- Textbook of Forensic Medicine and toxicology Page 438

questions.text: During an autopsy of a road traffic accident victim apparent bleeding was seen on the surface of his brain. Which type of hemorrhage would not be washed away under direct running water?
questions.solution: Subarachnoid haemorrhage will persist when washed under running water during an autopsy. Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding in the space between the brain and the arachnoid membrane which is the subarachnoid space. the blood from a subarachnoid haemorrhage is not easily washed away by running water as it is located in this deep layer, which can trap the blood within the brain's sulci and gyri, beneath the very thin and transparent arachnoid layer. Ref- Ziu E, Khan Suheb MZ, Mesfin FB. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage. [Updated 2023 Jun 1]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-.

questions.text: A male was brought with the following injury in a gunshot incident. What is the possible range from which the weapon inflicted injury?
questions.solution:
A stellate wound is a star-shaped wound often seen in gunshot injuries to the scalp, due to the inelastic nature of the scalp tissue.

  • Close shot: The firearm is discharged close to the target, usually within a few centimeters to a meter. Stellate wounds are characteristic of close-range shots because the tissue is pushed outward by the muzzle blast, creating the star-like appearance.

  • Contact shot: The gun is pressed against the skin; usually produces muzzle imprint and soot deposition, not typically a stellate pattern.

  • Near shot: Slightly further than contact; can produce tattooing and soot deposition.

  • Distant shot: Bullet impacts without soot or powder burns; stellate wounds are not seen.

Hence, a stellate wound indicates a close-range gunshot.


 



Reference: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology 2nd edition page nos 280 and 283

questions.text: A body was brought in for post-mortem examination, and the following can be seen. What type of wounds are these?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular and ragged cut wounds over the palmar surface of the hands and fingers, which is suggestive of defense wounds. Defense wounds are the wounds that occur as a result of the victim's attempt to save himself from an injury.

It can be active or passive. Active defense wounds occur when the victim tries to grasp the weapon, while passive wounds result when the victim raises the hands, arms, or legs in an attempt to protect the eyes, head, or neck.

The morphology of the wound depends upon the type of weapon and the attack. In a sharp injury due to a single-edged weapon, a single cut may be seen on the palm or the bends of fingers. In the case of a double-edged sharp weapon, cuts are seen on both palm and fingers. The cuts are irregular in-depth and are ragged.

The defense wounds signify homicide, and in females, they often indicate sexual assault.

Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 35th edition page no 147,156-157,238-239

questions.text: Identify the odor produced by the change seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
• Definition:
    Mummification is a form of modified putrefaction that occurs when the body dehydrates in the absence of moisture.
    It typically happens in hot, dry environments and results in preservation of the natural features and shape of the body.

  • Key Characteristics:

    • The body becomes dry, leathery, shrunken, and brown to black in color.

    • It is often odorless.

    • Natural features like facial expressions and outlines may remain intact.

      Essential Elements for Mummification:

  • Dry and warm air

  • Absence of moisture

    Favorable Conditions for Mummification:

  • Presence of dry air currents

  • Shallow graves

  • Hot weather

  • Dry, sandy soil


Reference: Synopsis of forensic medicine and toxicology 28th edition page no 99

questions.text: Identify the postmortem finding in a patient with a stab wound on the left side of the chest.
questions.solution:
Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition caused by accumulation of fluid (usually blood) in the pericardial sac, leading to compression of the heart, impaired ventricular filling, and reduced cardiac output.

Causes

  1. Crush Injuries

    • Sudden blunt trauma (e.g., road traffic accidents) → rapid blood accumulation.

  2. Penetrating Injuries

    • Left ventricle: Slower leak; chance for surgical repair.

    • Right ventricle: Thin wall; leads to rapid fatal tamponade.

  3. Fractures

    • Rib/sternal fractures may cause delayed cardiac injury → tamponade → shock/hemorrhage.


Treatment 

  • Immediate pericardiocentesis (needle drainage of pericardial fluid)

  • Volume expansion and oxygen to support circulation

  • Surgical repair (if due to trauma or persistent bleeding)


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1843

questions.text: A lucid interval is classically associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A lucid interval is a characteristic clinical feature of extradural (epidural) hemorrhage, typically following head trauma.

Classic Presentation:

  1. Initial loss of consciousness after trauma.

  2. Followed by a lucid interval (patient regains consciousness and appears normal).

  3. Then a rapid deterioration occurs as the hematoma expands, causing increased intracranial pressure.

    Cause:

  • Usually due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery from a temporal bone fracture.

  • Blood collects between the dura mater and the skull.

    Other Options:

  • Parenchymal hemorrhage: No lucid interval; causes focal deficits or coma.

  • Subdural hemorrhage: Slow venous bleed; lucid interval possible but less classic.

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Sudden severe headache; no lucid interval.


Reference:Knights forensic pathology 4th edition page no 184

questions.text: A doctor receives a case of homicide. Under which section is he supposed to inform the police
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. 39

Section 39 CrPC: "Every person, aware of the commission of, or of the intention of any other person to commit, any offence punishable under any of the following sections of the Indian Penal Code, shall, in the absence of any reasonable excuse, the burden of proving which excuse shall lie upon the person so aware, forthwith give information to the nearest Magistrate or police officer of such commission or intention"

Hence under section 39 CrPC, it's the duty of the doctor to inform the police. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 514.

choices.text: Doctor is guilty under “Last clear chance” doctrine
Doctor is guilty as he prescribed wrong medicines

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon urged a patient to get his wound dressed on a daily basis. However, the patient was unconcerned. During follow-up, the patient was frequently told to get the dressing done on time, but the patient refused, claiming that he was too busy. Finally, the wound grew larger, and the underlying bone became infected with osteomyelitis.
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the correct answer.

The concept of "contributory negligence" applies when the plaintiff's own negligence contributes to their injury or damages. In this case, the patient's failure to follow the doctor's advice and get the dressing done on time resulted in the worsening of the wound and later development of osteomyelitis. Therefore, the patient should be considered to have contributed to their own injury.


Other options

Option 1
â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹The "last clear chance" doctrine is a legal principle that applies to cases of contributory negligence, where both the plaintiff and defendant were negligent, but the defendant had the last clear chance to avoid harm. However, in this situation, the doctor did not have the last clear chance to prevent harm, as the patient had the opportunity to take care of the wound by getting the dressing done on time.

Option 3
Negligence is the failure to take reasonable care that a prudent person would take in similar circumstances. If the doctor failed to provide adequate instructions or follow-up care, or if the doctor prescribed the wrong medicines, then they may be held liable for avoidable negligence. However, based on the information provided in the question, there is no evidence that the doctor committed avoidable negligence.

Option 4
The question does not provide any information to suggest that the doctor prescribed the wrong medicines. Therefore, it is incorrect to state that the doctor is guilty of prescribing wrong medicines.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Within how much time should a patient’s records on demand be provided in case of professional misconduct?

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient with altered sensorium is taken to the emergency room. An urgent neurosurgery procedure was required after a non-contrast CT indicated hydrocephalus. The patient was alone and didn't have any identification with them. Which of the following provisions of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) permits the neurosurgeon to carry out the treatment without a guardian's informed consent?
questions.solution:
In the given case Section 92 of IPC is applicable because the intervention was done by the doctor in good faith and as it was not possible to obtain consent form the patient.
  • Section 87 IPC: A person above 18 years of age can give consent to suffer any harm if the act is not intended and not known to cause death or grievous hurt.
  • Section 89 IPC: A child under 12 years of age or a person of unsound mind cannot give consent to suffer any harm for an act which may cause grievous hurt or death even if done in good faith, but the consent has to be obtained from the guardian of the child or a sane person.
  • Section 90 IPC: Consent given by an insane person or given under fear of injury, death etc. or due to misconception of a fact is invalid.
  • Section 92 IPC: Any harm caused to a person in good faith even without the person's consent is not an offence if the circumstances were such that it was impossible to obtain consent of the person or his lawful guardian at that material time for that thing to be done for the benefit of the person. However the act should not extend to intentionally causing hurt other than for preventing death, grievous hurt or curing of disease or infirmity.
  • If a patient is unconscious and there is imminent danger to his life and there is no designated person to give a consent then acc. To S. 92 IPC the law presumes that consent has been deemed to be given (can be an example of Implied Consent). If the emergency treatment is no longer required or patient is fit to give consent or a guardian/relative is present then doctrine of implied consent do not govern.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 53.

questions.text: The same needle that was used on a patient who had HIV was also used on another patient. The latter patient is confirmed to have HIV infection, according to tests. Which part of the Indian penal code penalises the doctor for this negligence?

Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six month, or with fine, or with both.

questions.text: Within five years of her marriage, a woman passed away under mysterious circumstances. The frequent dowry demands made by her in-laws were a source of complaint for her parents. Which of the following sections permits the magistrate to order an autopsy in such a case?

questions.text: Which provision of the IPC does the M'Naughten Rule fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: IPC 84
 
  • McNaughten's rule falls under IPC 84. Mc Naughten’s rule also known as the McNaughten test or the right-wrong test, is a legal standard used in some jurisdictions to determine the criminal responsibility of individuals with mental disorders.
  • The rule focuses on the cognitive aspect of the defendant's mental state. It states that a defendant is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, they were suffering from a mental disorder that affected their ability to understand the nature and quality of the act.
  • The burden of proof rests on the defendant, who must establish the defense of insanity.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 493.

Option 2: Article 21-A states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.

Option 4: Article 24 says that “No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.”

questions.text: The burden of proof in a civil negligence against the doctor lies with
questions.solution:
•  In a civil negligence case, the burden of proof is on the patient to prove that the doctor has breached a duty of care owed to the patient, that it led to the injury or damage sustained, and that it actually caused the damage.
  • The patient must demonstrate that the doctor acted in a way that did not meet the applicable standards of care, that the breach directly led to the injury or damage, and that the injury or damage is real and measurable.
  • The burden of proof then rests with the doctor to prove that he or she acted reasonably and that the injury or damage was caused by factors outside of the doctor's control. If the doctor can prove contributory negligence or that the injury or damage was caused by something else, them the patient may not be able to recover damages.
  • In the case of Res ipsa loquitur, the evidence speaks for itself, and the patient does not need to prove the elements of negligence.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 37.

questions.text: What does first hand knowledge refer to:
questions.solution:
A common witness must provide first-hand knowledge in order to be acceptable in court. This means that the witness must be able to testify about facts that were seen or heard by that individual alone, rather than learned from another source. Essentially, the witness must have experienced it with their own senses, and be able to testify to that effect. For example, when testifying in a case of a traffic accident, the witness must have seen the accident happen with their own eyes.\

questions.text: A patient was planned for a surgical procedure and due consent was taken. However during surgery - the surgeon feels the need to remove more tissue to save the life of patient than what was taken consent for. Doctor can proceed and will not be liable under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option 4. Doctrine of extended consent

The surgeon can proceed without liability under the Doctrine of extended consent if they are required to remove more tissue to save the patient's life. It allows the surgeon to act beyond the initial consent if it is necessary to save the patient's life or prevent serious harm. Extended consent acknowledges that the patient has consented to the procedure in general terms, and the doctor can proceed with additional necessary steps that go beyond the specific details of the original consent.

Other options
  • M'naghten rule: This rule is related to criminal law and the insanity defense, not relevant to medical consent
  • Res Ipsa Loquitor: This is a legal doctrine that allows an inference of negligence in certain cases where the harm caused is so obvious that it speaks for itself (eg. leaving scissors inside abdomen during surgery). It doesn't apply in the context of consent in medical procedures.
  • Doctrine of conjugated consent: This term isn't commonly used in medical legal contexts and doesn't directly relate to the issue of extending consent during surgery.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 49.

questions.text: Even with careful precautions, the ureter is harmed intraoperatively when performing a hysterectomy after receiving informed permission for uterine fibroids. According to which principle is Dr. not accountable?
questions.solution:
The doctor is not responsible for the events under the doctrine of Medical mal-occurrence.
 
Since the doctor took diligent measures and even after that harm was caused to the patient, the doctor is not responsible under the Doctrine of Medical mal-occurrence which states that every person has a different response to different drugs and procedures and even after the most diligent efforts, harm may occur but the doctor is not responsible for these outcomes.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 49.

questions.text: A photosensitive lesion on the malar area of the patient's face, who is 40 years old, has been brought to the skin OPD. The kind of consent given in this instance is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Implied consent.

Implied consent refers to a form of consent that is not explicitly expressed but is assumed based on the circumstances and conduct of the individual. Implied consent is often relied upon in situations where explicit consent may not be practical or necessary, such as routine medical examinations or emergency medical treatment.

E.g., patient extends their arm to allow a healthcare professional to take their blood pressure

Option 1: Blanket consent refers to a broad, general consent given by an individual that covers a range of activities or procedures without specifying each one individually. 

E.g., A patient admitted in the ward need not provide consent for blood collection, routine vaccination.

Option 2: Informed consent is a voluntary and explicit agreement given by an individual after being provided with adequate information about the nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives of a particular procedure, treatment, or activity.

E.g., Before undergoing surgery.

Option 3: Expressed consent, also known as explicit consent, is a clear and direct verbal or written agreement given by an individual to authorize a specific action, procedure, or activity. 

E.g., A person signing a document or verbally stating "Yes, I agree" to participate in a research study is providing expressed consent for their involvement.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 32.

questions.solution:
