questions.text: A doctor was drunk and he performed a major surgery on a patient. Mistakenly he injured a major artery and the patient died. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of criminal negligence on the part of doctor. 

Criminal negligence is when a doctor lacks a gross skill or care while treating causing serious injury/death of the patient. 

Most of the cases occur due to drunkenness or usage of drugs. 
 
  • Criminal negligence involves gross negligence or reckless disregard for the safety of others, leading to serious harm or death.
  • In this case, the doctor performed surgery while intoxicated, which is an act of reckless behavior and a severe deviation from the standard of care, leading to the patient's death. This qualifies as criminal negligence.
Other options: 
 
  1. Dichotomy: Refers to an unethical practice where a physician receives a commission for referring patients, unrelated to this scenario.
  2. Therapeutic misadventure: Refers to an unintended and unavoidable adverse outcome of a medical procedure despite appropriate care. This does not apply here because the doctor's actions were reckless and preventable.
  3. Civil negligence: Involves failure to meet the standard of care, leading to harm. While this is also negligence, it is not "criminal" unless there is gross or willful misconduct, as in this case.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 40, 41, 46, 646.

questions.text: A doctor explained the benefits and risks of doing a surgical procedure to the patient. After that the patient signed the consent form. This is known as:
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the patient has been made aware of the benefits an complications of the procedure to which the patient has agreed. 
 
  • This is an example of informed consent.
 
  • Informed consent occurs when a healthcare provider explains the nature of a medical procedure, including its benefits, risks, and alternatives, and the patient voluntarily agrees to proceed, often by signing a consent form. This process ensures the patient understands and consents to the procedure based on adequate information.
     

Other options:

  • Implied consent: This is assumed in situations where consent is not explicitly given, such as in emergencies when a patient is unconscious and unable to provide consent.
  • Therapeutic privilege: This refers to a situation where a doctor withholds information from a patient if disclosing it could cause harm to the patient's mental or physical health.
  • Informed refusal: This happens when a patient, after being informed of the benefits and risks, chooses to decline the procedure.

In the scenario described, the patient was informed and willingly signed the consent form, indicating informed consent.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 50, 51.

questions.text: Patient with h/o previous surgery comes to hospital with abdominal pain and fever. X-ray abdomen shows the following finding. This corresponds to:
questions.solution:
• Res ipsa loquitur is latin for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • It is sufficient to prove the negligence of any doctor.
  • E.g. Wrong dose in prescription cards, presence of swab/ instrument in patient's body following surgery.
  • It can be proof of civil and criminal negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur is a Latin term meaning "the thing speaks for itself." It is a legal doctrine used in cases where the negligence is so obvious that it requires no further proof. In this scenario, the presence of scissors left in the abdomen after surgery is clear evidence of negligence, fitting the concept of Res ipsa loquitur.


Other options:
 

  1. Res Judicata - A legal principle meaning "a matter already judged." It prevents the same case from being tried again once it has been resolved.
  2. Novus actus interveniens - A new, independent act that breaks the chain of causation in a legal case. This is not applicable here.
  3. Vicarious liability - Legal responsibility of a superior (e.g., hospital) for the acts of their subordinates (e.g., a surgeon). While the hospital may be liable, this concept does not directly apply to the scenario described.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 38, 39, 45-47.

questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'C' saw 'A' with knife in the park few minutes before the murder. 'C' gives this statement in the court of law. What kind of evidence is this?
questions.solution:
• Direct evidence is a direct confirmation of a fact, such as a witness' testimony regarding what they personally witnessed, heard, or did.
  • Indirect evidence, such as circumstantial evidence, is proof of one or more facts from which another fact can be inferred.
  • In this case, 'C' did not witness the actual murder but observed 'A' with a knife in the park shortly before the incident. Therefore, the evidence indirectly suggests the possibility of 'A' being involved in the crime.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 9,13 .

Killing of fetus with consent of mother
Killing of fetus without consent of mother
Killing fetus in an attempt to kill the mother amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 of IPC deals with:-
questions.solution:
The legal aspects of criminal abortion are dealt with under sections 312 to 316 of the IPC.

Section 314 of the IPC - death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage:
  • Intent: causing miscarriage of a pregnant woman
  • Act: Causes death of woman (killing of mother); irrespective of whether that offender knew that the act is likely to cause death
  • Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 10 years and fine.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 401.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered to be grievious injury?
questions.solution:
Grievious hurt has following clauses
  1. Emasculation
  2. Permanent privation of sight of either eye
  3. Permanent privation of hearing of either ear
  4. Privation of any member or joint Destruction or permanent impairment of any member or joint
  5. Permanent disfigurement of head or face
  6. Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth
  7. Any hurt which endangers life or causes sufferer to be in severe body pain or unable to follow his daily activities for 20 days
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page. No: 225.

questions.text: 13y old unmarried girl was brought to the emergency after abdominal pain. After examination she was found to be 8 weeks pregnant. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
All the above steps are indicated but the next best step would be to Register an MLC and inform the Police as it is a Medico Legal case. Section 21 of POCSO act requires mandatory reporting of child sexual abuse to law enforcement authorities.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page. No- 330, 331.

questions.text: When measuring the barrel of a rifled firearm, the caliber of the weapon depends on?
questions.solution:
• The caliber of a rifled firearm is the nominal internal diameter of the bore. It is measured as the distance between the tops of two opposite lands (the raised portions between the grooves).

  • The groove-to-groove distance corresponds to the groove or bullet diameter, but the standard definition of caliber uses land-to-land measurement.

  • High-yield point: When asked about caliber measurement in a rifled barrel, choose land-to-land, unless the question specifically refers to the bullet or groove diameter.

choices.text: Non entry in MTP register & not sending reports to DHS
MTP done up to 24 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is a punishable offence with regard to MTP guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971 (amended 2021) and the MTP Rules, 2003, it is mandatory that:

  • Every registered medical practitioner (RMP) performing MTP must maintain a permanent record in the prescribed Form III (MTP register).

  • The RMP or the medical officer-in-charge must submit a monthly report of all MTPs conducted to the Chief Medical Officer (CMO)/District Health Society (DHS) in Form II.

Failure to maintain the register or send the reports is considered a punishable offence under the Act.

Other options:

  • MTP done by experienced RMP:
    Allowed, provided the RMP is trained and approved under the Act. Not an offence.

  • MTP done at government authorized center:
    Legally permitted and safe, not an offence.

  • MTP done up to 24 weeks of pregnancy:
    Permitted under the 2021 Amendment for specific categories of women (e.g., rape survivors, minors, etc.) after opinion of two RMPs. Not an offence.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mentally challenged pregnant female was brought to the hospital for MTP Consent in this case will be given by?
questions.solution:
In India, the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971 (amended in 2021) lays down clear rules regarding who can give consent for termination of pregnancy.

In this case — a 22-year-old mentally challenged (mentally ill) woman — consent cannot be taken from her directly, even though she is an adult.
The law treats mentally ill women differently from mentally retarded or minor women regarding consent.

  • Under Section 3(4)(a) of the MTP Act:
    âž¤ If the woman is an adult (above 18 years) and mentally sound, her own written consent is sufficient.

  • Under Section 3(4)(b) of the MTP Act:
    âž¤ If the woman is mentally ill, consent must be obtained from her guardian.

  • However, in mentally challenged or severely retarded women, especially when there is doubt about her ability to consent, the Court or Magistrate may be approached to authorize the procedure — particularly when pregnancy may be due to sexual assault or exploitation.

Hence, in this mentally challenged (not mentally sound) adult woman, consent from the legal guardian is obtained.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female was raped two years back. Who has the authority to impose a death sentence on the convicted accused?
questions.solution:
Under Indian law, cases of rape are tried in Sessions Court if the offence is punishable with imprisonment of seven years or more, including life imprisonment or death penalty in rare cases.

  • Death sentence: Only a Sessions Court has the legal authority to impose the death penalty for crimes like rarest of rare rape cases.

  • Magistrate’s Court, District Court, Assistant Sessions Court: Do not have the power to award death sentences; they can impose imprisonment and fines as per their jurisdiction.

Key point:

Death penalty for rape can only be awarded by the Sessions Court in India.

questions.text: A newly married female patient who is 22 weeks pregnant came in for MTP on the grounds of contraceptive failure. MTP can be performed after?
questions.solution:
In India, according to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act 2021:

  • Abortions up to 20 weeks of gestation can be performed on the opinion of one registered medical practitioner.

  • Abortions between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation require the opinion of two registered medical practitioners, and can be performed only under specific circumstances, such as contraceptive failure in a married woman, risk to the mother’s physical or mental health, or fetal abnormalities.

  • Abortions beyond 24 weeks are generally not allowed, except in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities, and require permission from a Medical Board.

In this scenario:

  • Gestational age: 22 weeks

  • Ground: contraceptive failure

    Therefore, MTP can be performed with the opinion of 2 doctors.

questions.text: Which of the following decleration concerns therapeutic abortion
questions.solution:
• Declaration of Oslo refers to therapeutic abortion
  • Declaration of Helenski is concerned with human experimentation.
  • Deceleration of Sydney is on human death: states that determination of death "will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids", such as EEG.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No 493.

questions.text: Inquest in a case of custodial death is handled by
questions.solution:
Inquest in Custodial Death Cases
An inquest for cases of custodial death is conducted by an Executive Magistrate.

According to Section 176 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cr.P.C), a magistrate inquest can be performed by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, a magistrate of first-class rank, or any other magistrate designated by the State Government, such as a Collector, Deputy Collector, or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates).

This type of inquest is required in the following circumstances:

Death occurring under police custody
Death resulting from police firing
Deaths that occur in prisons, reformatories, or borstal schools
Dowry deaths
Deaths in a psychiatric hospital
Cases involving exhumation
Death or disappearance of any person, or the rape of a woman in the custody of police or any other person authorized by the court.
In these situations, the magistrate may conduct the inquest independently or in conjunction with a police inquest.

questions.text: According to the law, nothing is an offence if a person is of an unsound mind and is not able to understand that the nature and consequences of his/her act are wrong. Which rule of insanity applies in this case?
questions.solution:
McNaughten's Rule is the correct principle regarding the defense of insanity. It states, "Nothing is an offense if it is committed by a person who, at the time of the act, is incapable of understanding the nature of the act or knowing that it is wrong due to unsoundness of mind."

The key elements of McNaughten's Rule include:

Every individual is presumed to be sane and has a sufficient degree of reasoning to be held accountable for their actions until proven otherwise.

To successfully establish an insanity defense, it must be clearly demonstrated that at the time of the offense, the accused was suffering from a mental defect due to a disease of the mind, which rendered them unable to comprehend the nature and quality of the act they were committing, or if they were aware of it, that they did not understand it was wrong.

questions.text: A public witness of the incident is asked to attend the court and record his evidence. Which type of evidence is provided by the witness to the court?
questions.solution:
Definition: Evidence provided verbally by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts surrounding a particular incident, typically referred to as an eyewitness.

Legal Framework: Under Section 60 of the Indian Evidence Act, oral evidence should be direct whenever possible, meaning the witness should provide firsthand accounts rather than hearsay.

Components:

Includes all statements made by the witness related to the inquiry.
The witness must have witnessed the event or have direct knowledge pertinent to the case.

Key Points:
Oral evidence plays a crucial role in legal proceedings as it can significantly influence the court's understanding of the facts.
The reliability and credibility of the witness can impact the weight given to their oral testimony.
This understanding is essential in legal contexts to appreciate the value of eyewitness accounts and the principles governing their admissibility in court.

questions.text: Who conducts the inquest in case of a death of a prisoner?
questions.solution:
A magistrate inquest will be carried out for death under police custody.
Indications for Magistrate Inquest:
• Death under police custody
• Death due to police firing
• Death in prison, reformatories, borstal schools
• Dowry death
• Death in a psychiatric hospital
• Exhumation
• Death or disappearance of any person, or rape of a woman who is under the custody of police or any other person authorized by the court. Ref- The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 35th edition • Page no 5-6

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child has generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk, appearing 2 days after fever, which is characteristic of varicella (chickenpox).

  • Lesions appear in crops, starting on the trunk and spreading to extremities, and are vesicular on an erythematous base.

Other options:

  • Shingles: Usually unilateral, dermatomal distribution; occurs in older children/adults.

  • Monkeypox: Vesicular-pustular lesions with often central umbilication, associated with lymphadenopathy.

  • Smallpox: More severe, lesions are centrifugal, firm, synchronous in stage, and absence of crops.


Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 25.27-25.28

questions.text: In a suspected murder case, the court summoned a doctor to provide his opinion and testify as a witness.Doctor in such a scenario is commonly referred to as __?
questions.solution:
• A doctor summoned to give professional opinion in a legal case is called an expert witness. They provide specialized knowledge to help the court understand medical aspects of the case.

Other options:

  • Oral evidence: Refers to testimony given by any witness in court, not specifically an expert.

  • Hostile witness: A witness who shows antagonism or unwillingness to testify in favor of the party that called them.

  • Common witness: A regular witness who provides factual information without specialized expertise.

Reference:The essentials of Forensic medicine and Toxicology 33rd edition page no 12-16

questions.text: A newly married female patient, 21 weeks pregnant, underwent a fetal USG which showed myelomeningocele of the fetus. The doctor proposed medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). Which of the following is mandatory in this case? a. Patient's consent b. Patient's partner's consent c. Opinion of 1 doctor d. Opinion of 2 doctors
questions.solution:
• According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, for termination beyond 20 weeks of gestation (like in this case at 21 weeks), termination is allowed only when two registered medical practitioners (RMPs) give their opinion that continuation of pregnancy would involve risk to the mother or substantial fetal abnormalities.

  • Patient’s informed consent is mandatory.

  • Partner’s consent is not required.

Other options:

  • c only: One doctor’s opinion is insufficient for >20 weeks.

  • d only: Patient consent is also mandatory.

  • b and d: Partner’s consent is not required.



Reference
The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page nos 47,49

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a radiologist for a CT scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
Dichotomy is an unethical practice in which a referring doctor accepts a fee or commission from another medical professional (e.g., a radiologist, laboratory, or pharmacist) in exchange for patient referrals.

Important Points:

  • It is not only unethical but also illegal in many countries, including India.

  • The Medical Council of India (MCI) or the National Medical Commission (NMC) strictly prohibits this practice.

  • It violates principles of medical ethics, particularly those related to patient welfare and autonomy.

    What other options mean:

  • Medical maloccurence: A rare or unfortunate medical event, often used vaguely; not a standard ethical term.

  • Commission: While commission can mean a fee for services, in medical ethics, it lacks specificity unless used in the context of dichotomy.

  • Criminal negligence: Gross negligence resulting in patient harm or death — not applicable here unless direct harm occurs.



Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 646

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Teichmann test:
 

Purpose:
To confirm the presence of blood in a stain, especially in forensic investigations.

Principle:

  • The test detects hematin crystals (known as haemin crystals) formed when blood hemoglobin reacts with glacial acetic acid and a chloride-containing salt (e.g., sodium chloride).

  • These crystals are brown rhombic plates, visible under a microscope.



    Procedure Summary:

  1. A small quantity of the suspected blood stain is scraped and placed on a glass slide.

  2. A drop of glacial acetic acid and a few crystals of NaCl are added.

  3. Gently heat the slide without boiling.

  4. Cool and observe under a microscope for brown rhombic crystals.

    Differentiation from Other Tests:

Test Name Detects Crystal Appearance
Teichmann test Haemin (hemin) Brown rhombic plates
Takayama test Hemochromogen Pink feathery crystals
Florence test Choline (in semen) Brown needle-shaped crystals
Barberio test Spermine (in semen) Needle-shaped crystals

Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 434 and 451

questions.text: Pick the most common cause of parasuicide.
questions.solution:
Parasuicide is an attempt at suicide or self-harm in which there may be no actual intention of dying or death. Most cases of parasuicide are due to Drug Overdose.
Hence, option (1) is the correct answer. The second most common cause is cutting the wrist.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 506.

questions.text: Where is the knot tied in a judicial hanging?
questions.solution:
The knot used in judicial hanging is positioned at the angle of the jaw.

Judicial Hanging: It is believed that the fastest death occurs when the knot is positioned beneath the chin (submental position).
However, in India & UK, left sub aural (below angle of jaw) knot is preferred for hanging.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: Which among the following results in death if the Jack-knife position is maintained for too long?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Positional asphyxia.

Accidental death from postural or positional asphyxia takes place when the abnormal jack knife position of the victim's body compromises the process of respiration.

 

Option 1: wedging is when a child or infant falls in the small gap between the bed and the wall when asleep. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.



Option 2: Burking is when a person sits on the chest of another person putting pressure on it and closes the mouth and nostrils as well.

 


Option 4: Traumatic asphyxia occurs due to mechanical fixation of chest. It can occur in stampedes or when a heavy weight object falls on chest.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 364.

questions.text: An autopsy was done on a woman who had been brought dead to the hospital. No distinct indicators were noticed. Only the chin mark depicted below was visible upon exterior inspection; nevertheless, during inside inspection, the following appearance was discovered. What's the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Throttling.

The first image is showing multiple bruises resembling the pulp of fingertips.
The second image is showing collection of blood due to rupture of artery which will present in the form of contusion. These are features of manual Strangulation also known as Throttling.

Option 1: Closing of mouth and nostrils together is known as smothering. Frenulum tear, perioral injuries will be the classical features present.



Option 3: Suspension of the body by a ligature is known as hanging. Death occurs due to Asphyxia and cerebral venous congestion. 

Option 4: Transverse and below thyroid ligature mark will be present. Bruises can be present around ligature mark.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: The most common method of suicide in India, according to the National Crime Bureau, is:
questions.solution:
Prominent mode of suicides as per NCRB 2022 report-
1. Hanging (58.2%)
2. Poison (25.4%)

4. Coming under running vehicles/train (2.9%)

questions.text:
A woman's body was discovered in her bedroom. The door to the room was not closed. 350 mg/dL of alcohol in the blood was shown along with images of the face,
open neck, and viscera. A picture was provided showing cyanosed lips and probable six-penny bruises on the neck. Soft tissue ecchymosis was visible in the
dissected neck. What is the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Presence of bruises in the neck,cyanosed lip and Dissected neck showing soft tissue ecchymosis is highly suggestive of throttling.
 
  • Throttling, also known as manual strangulation:
  • Throttling is the asphyxia that results from the compression of the neck by human hands. Carotid artery blockage is the cause of death. Occlusion of the airway has a small impact.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: Choking is observed in:
questions.solution:
Choking is a process that uses mechanical constrictions at the end of the barrel of a shotgun to shape the spread of the gun’s shot.

The larger internal diameter of the barrel holds more shot, allowing more pellets to be fired with one pull of the trigger. The choke mechanism at the end of the barrel narrows the spread of the shot. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 362.

questions.text:
An autopsy was done on a woman who had been brought dead to the hospital. No distinct indicators were noticed. Only the chin mark depicted below was visible
upon exterior inspection; nevertheless, during inside inspection, the following appearance was discovered: What's the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The case appears to be of Throttling.

External inspection reveals a single abrasion, most likely the result of the attacker's fingers grabbing the neck. Additionally, neck bruising was observed. Internal examination reveals injured neck tissues with haemorrhage from the strap muscles. All of these characteristics imply throttling. In the absence of a ligature mark, hanging can be ruled out. Strangulation by ligature cannot exist if there is no ligature mark.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

choices.text: Blackish soot deposit on posterior part of tongue

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with severe burns was brought to the emergency room. On the patient's face, back, upper arms, and forearms in addition to hair burning, there were grade 3 burns. Which of the following is not evidence of burns from inhalation?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Yellow colored sputum

The following signs are seen in a patient with smoke inhalation injury:
  • Facial burns
  • Burned lips and nasal hair
  • Hoarseness, coughing, stridor
  • Dyspnea
  • Soot in nostrils and mouth
  • Airway edema
  • Carbonaceous sputum
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Neurological deficits (unconsciousness, nausea, vomiting, vertigo).
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 323.

questions.text:
Which of the following anomalies is observed in a case of drowning in sea water?
i. Hypernatremia
ii. Hypercalcemia
iii. Hypermagnesemia
iv. Hyponatremia
v. Myocardial anoxia
questions.solution:
Due to the osmotic pressure effect, the salt water that has entered the lungs and is hypertonic takes water from the blood in pulmonary circulation.
This causes fulminating pulmonary edema, hemoconcentration, hypovolemia of the blood, hypoxia, and circulatory shock, which are all followed by cardiac standstill or systole and death. Hemoconcentration leads to Myocardial anoxia. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: A case of a hanging victim is brought in for an autopsy. Upon inspection, the right eye was open, and saliva was seen trickling from the mouth. Which of the following structures is compressed, causing the right eye to open
questions.solution:
Hanging is a type of asphyxial death in which there is neck compression and body suspension. Eye on the opposide side of knot remains open and pupil dilated due to compression of cervical sympathetic ganglion. This is one of the signs of antemortem hanging, known as La facies Sympathique.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 344.

questions.text:
Correct statement about fresh water drowning is: 
a. Hemodilution
b.Hyperkalemia
c.Hyponatremia
d.Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
All of the given options are correct about fresh water drowning.

In case of fresh water drowning, the water which fills the lungs is hypotonic compared to blood. This causes dilution of the plasma leading to hemodilution, hyponatremia and  swelling of RBCs and further their lysis.

This lysis causes release of potassium present within the RBCs into the plasma causing hyperkalemia, which leads to arrythmias.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for death for a 22-year-old female with bleeding in her eyes and neck bruising?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death, based on the facts in the inquiry and the provided photographs, could be throttling.

There will be ligature marks in the neck region in the event of hanging or ligature strangling. There is no ligature mark visible in this instance.

Hemorrhage in eyes are associated with cases of throttling and not drowning.

Manual Strangulation/Throttling: It is a type of strangulation where bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate. Cause of death is Asphyxia.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

choices.text: Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

questions.text: What causes the below phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This example of prolonged submersion in water (over 36 hours) is marked by skin mottling and a greenish black discoloration brought on by putrefactive alterations.

This picture is also referred to as ‘Washerwoman feet’, a non-specific sign of drowning.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 368.

choices.text: Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus
Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation
Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death

questions.text: Except for ______, each of the following statements regarding the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is accurate.
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3. "Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation."
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus, which was first described by Prinsloo and Gordon.
  • However, it is not a definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation.
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a post-mortem finding that is commonly seen in cases of manual strangulation. It is caused by the rupture of the small veins in the mucosa of the posterior wall of the esophagus due to the pressure applied during the act of strangulation.
  • The hemorrhage appears as a linear or crescent-shaped mark on the posterior wall of the esophagus and is usually located between the level of the cricoid cartilage and the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • While the presence of the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is highly suggestive of death due to manual strangulation, it is not a definitive sign.
  • Other causes of the hemorrhage, such as forceful vomiting or resuscitation attempts, can also result in the appearance of the artefact.
  • Therefore, a thorough investigation, including a detailed examination of the body and the circumstances surrounding the death, is necessary to determine the cause and manner of death.
Prinsloo and Gordon artefact is seen in all types of autopsies and is present over posterior surface of esophagus, trachea and anterior longitudnal ligament of cervical spine. It is due to postmortem staining. It must not be confused as hemorrhage which can cause misinterpretation the case as a manual strangulation. That is why before dissection neck structures must be inspected in situ. Also before opening neck, head and thorax must be opened to achieve bloodless neck dissection.

Reference: Pollanen MS. Pitfalls and Artifacts in the Neck at Autopsy. Acad Forensic Pathol. 2016 Mar;6(1):45-62. doi: 10.23907/2016.005. Epub 2016 Mar 1. PMID: 31239872; PMCID: PMC6474509.

questions.text: A condition known as 'la facies sympathique' is present in cases of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Hanging.
  • In a patient of hanging, the ligature knot puts a pressure on the opposite Cervical Sympathetic ganglion. This causes the eye on the opposite side of the knot to remain open and the pupil gets dilated.
  • A common misconception is that cervical ganglion of the same side as the ligature knot gets compressed which is wrong. In a case of hanging the fixed knot almost never comes in contact with the skin (ligature does not encircle the neck completely). Maximum pressure is exerted on the opposite side of the knot and thus the opposite cervical ganglion gets compressed. The eye on that side is dilated.
  • This is caused by the increased pressure in the veins of the head and neck due to the obstruction of blood flow from the heart to the head. Option 1, Hanging, is the correct answer because this condition is specific to death by hanging and is not present in other causes of death such as strangulation, myocardial insufficiency, or railway accidents. In cases of strangulation, the appearance of the face may be different due to the different mechanism of death.
  • Myocardial insufficiency and railway accidents are also not associated with the characteristic appearance of the face seen in 'le facies sympathique'.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Ladder tears are :
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Transverse tears of aortic intima

An aortic rupture is circular and clean-cut, and appears as sharp as if it has been transected with a knife.

Sometimes multiple transverse intimal tears are seen adjacent to the main rupture called as "ladder tears."

The mechanism involves the sudden deceleration that occurs during a crash, which can cause the aorta to stretch and tear, especially at points where it is anchored or where there are natural anatomical variations.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 282.

questions.text: A dead body had a transverse ligature mark encircling the neck. The location was below the thyroid cartilage. There was no dribbling of saliva from the angle of mouth. This suggest:
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the ligature is completely encircling the neck, is horizontal and below the level of thyroid cartilage.
 
  • There is no associated dribbling of saliva. All these features go in favor of ligature strangulation-Option B. 
 
  • Option 1- Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of neck with the help of hands causing asphyxia. Thumb impressions and copper penny bruises are common findings on neck.


Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice, 5th edition, Page no 121.

questions.text: Identify the type of death?
questions.solution:
• Garrotting is a type of asphyxia in which throat may be grasped, or a ligature is thrown over the neck and quickly tightened, by twisting it with a lever, within the ligature, which results in sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. 
 
  • Garrotting as a mode of judicial execution was once employed in Spain.
 
  • An iron collar around the neck was tightened by a screw for strangling (Spanish Windlass).



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 350, 359, 360.

questions.text: Dead body of a child was recovered from a river with froth over the mouth which comes back even after wiping. Which of the following post-mortem findings will not be seen?
questions.solution:
Arsenic in hair is not related to the case.

Other features are seen in a case of drowning:
  • Cadaveric spasm is the surest sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Paltauf’s hemorrhages are patches of hemorrhages on the anterior aspect and margins of the lungs subpleurally. These are caused due to rupture of alveoli during forceful expiration, thus indicating great struggle as in drowning.

 



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 368, 369.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in dry drowning?

questions.text: A female was brought in for an autopsy with a reported history of being discovered at a village lake. Which of the following findings is NOT indicative of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
Antemortem Drowning Features:

External Features:

Froth: The most distinctive sign of antemortem drowning is the presence of abundant, fine, shaving-lather-like froth around the mouth and nostrils. This froth results from the agitation of tracheal and bronchial mucus, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during breathing efforts.

Cutis Anserina: This term describes the pucker and grainy appearance of the skin due to the contraction of the erector pili muscles, resembling goose skin.

Washerwoman‘s Hands and Feet: This refers to the wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance of the skin on the palms and soles due to maceration from submersion in water. It can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning cases.

Cadaveric Spasm: In cases of antemortem drowning, gravel, weeds, soil, and other materials may be firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This finding helps to indicate the location of the drowning.

Rigor Mortis: This appears early in cases involving a violent struggle before death.

Facial Appearance: The face may be bloated and discolored with cyanosis.

Eyes: The conjunctiva are often suffused, and the pupils may be dilated.

Tongue: It might be swollen and protruded.

Antemortem Injuries: These may result from striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water. These injuries should be examined only after the body is dry.


Internal Findings:

Lungs: They appear voluminous and distended, often showing ballooning. A cut section of the lungs will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.

Larynx, Trachea, and Bronchioles: The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in these areas is characteristic of antemortem drowning.

Heart and Blood Vessels: The Gettler test can be conducted to measure the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart, helping to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

Diatom Test: Diatoms, microscopic algae, can be found in the organs, especially in the bone marrow, and their presence suggests antemortem drowning.

Stomach and Small Intestines: These organs may contain water, with water in the small intestine being positive evidence of drowning.

Middle Ear: Water present in the middle ear is highly indicative of antemortem drowning.

Brain: The brain is typically congested, edematous, and may show loss of the gray-white matter junction.


Reference: Review Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects, Page no 179-182 .

questions.text: Identify the type of homicide caused by smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
questions.solution:
Burking is a form of homicidal asphyxial death that combines elements of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In this method, the assailant forces the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the victim's chest, restricting chest movements. The assailant then covers the victim's nose and mouth with their hands, effectively preventing the victim from breathing



Other options:

  • Bansdola → Method of homicidal ligature strangulation (common in India, using a twisted cloth or rope).

  • Garroting → Strangulation with a ligature, often from behind (typical of highway robberies in Spain/Latin America).

  • Mugging → Violent attack to rob someone, not a specific medicolegal asphyxial term.

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as
questions.solution:
Thanatology is the study of death in all its aspects, including the psychological, social, cultural, and medical considerations surrounding death.

Other Options:
Option A: Forensic anthropology is the application of physical anthropology in a legal context, focusing on the identification and analysis of human skeletal remains, particularly in forensic cases.

Option B: Molecular death refers to the process occurring at the cellular level after death, typically happening 1-2 hours post-mortem due to metabolic dysfunction and structural disintegration of cells and tissues.

Option D: Forensic toxicology involves the study of toxic substances and their effects on human beings, integrating medical and legal aspects to evaluate cases of poisoning or substance abuse in a forensic context.

questions.text: In a case of drowning, the following finding is seen at autopsy. What is it called?
questions.solution:
In drowning, if the victim was alive and struggling before death, you may find weeds, grass, or algae tightly clutched in the hands at autopsy. This is a classic sign of:

Cadaveric spasm (instantaneous rigor)


What is Cadaveric Spasm?

  • It is a sudden stiffening of muscles at the moment of death without the usual primary relaxation.

  • Seen in violent, emotional, or sudden deaths — like drowning, combat, suicide.

  • Only affects voluntary muscles (especially those in intense use at the moment of death).

  • Object in hand (e.g., grass, weeds, weapon) remains tightly gripped.

    Forensic Significance:

  • Indicates death was instantaneous and due to intense stress or struggle.

  • Presence of weeds/grass clenched in hands proves the person was alive at the time of submersion → Suggests antemortem drowning.


Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 369-372

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in "aggravated penetrative sexual assault" under the POCSO Act 2012?
questions.solution:
Threatening is not included under Aggravated penetrative sexual assault under POCSO act 2012.

According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses (POCSO) Act, a crime is considered to be "Aggravated" when it is done by someone who has the authority over or is in a position of trust over a child, such as a member of the security forces, a police officer, a public employee, etc.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: Within how many days a vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim?
questions.solution:
Vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim within 4 days.
 
  • Vaginal examination is done using a sterile speculum.
  • Examining the cervix, vaginal walls, and vault for redness, bruising, or tears. The case history, the amount of time that has passed since the assault and the examination, the type of assault, and whether or not she has showered or washed herself since the assault all influence the type of swabs and samples that are taken.
  • The likelihood of obtaining evidence is considerably diminished after 72 hours (3 days),but can be taken up to 96 hours (4 days).
  • After 96 hours, evidence from the outside of the body and from objects like clothing can be gathered.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures cannot be performed on a 14-year-old rape victim with 22 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Gynecologist can not abort the fetus upon the patient request.

Before performing an abortion, the woman's consent is essential. In the case of a woman who is under the age of 18 or mentally sick, parental written agreement is essential. Since the patient in the question is barely 14 years old, termination requires the guardian's agreement. Only up to 20 weeks of pregnancy may be terminated.

Therefore, a gynaecologist cannot perform an abortion at the patient's request.

Note- This Q has been framed according to older MTP guidelines. According to new MTP Act guidelines in case of rape victim, fetus can be aborted at anytime of gestation. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 401.

questions.text: What does a person with eonism find enjoyable?
questions.solution:
Transvestism or eonism is the practice of individuals identifying with and expressing themselves through the clothing, behaviour, and attitude typically associated with the opposite gender.
The term is derived from Chevalier d’Eon Beamont, a Frenchman who identified as a woman and often dressed in traditionally feminine attire. Transvestism is particularly common in men who derive sexual pleasure from wearing female clothing.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 432.

questions.text: Which instances of unnatural sexual offences are subject to the lateral traction test?
questions.solution:
Lateral traction test is done in unnatural sexual offences in habitual passive agent.

+ Lateral Buttock Traction Test -

• The lateral buttock traction test is a useful guide for determining a patient's habituation to anal intercourse. 

• The lateral buttock traction test involves placing the thumb on the cheeks of the buttock on either side of the anus and applying gentle lateral traction. 

• In patients who are not used to anal penetration (penile, instrumental, or otherwise), traction causes reflex constriction of the anal sphincter. 

• Patients who are used to anal penetration relax the sphincter in response to the lateral traction test.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: What happens to the hymen in a rape incidence involving a child of 5 years?
questions.solution:
In young children, there are usually few or no signs of general violence due to their lack of understanding of what is happening. Additionally, the hymen is deeply situated in the vagina so the penetration of the adult organ is not possible; the hymen is typically left intact and there is little redness or tenderness of the labia as a result.

questions.text: The mother of a 5-year-old kid brought him to the OPD complaining of perineal soreness. When examined, the sample of his perianal region that had been extracted with picric acid revealed yellow crystals of picrate. What kind of test is it?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is a microcrystal test for detection of spermine (secreted by prostate) in seminal stains. A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the dried stains and then examined under microscope.
Above reaction will produce yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This test can be positive without the presence of spermatozoa. But it tells that the test stain is a seminal stain.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 434.

questions.text:
The testing of Barberio is performed on a white cloth brought by the police.
Which of the following is detected in the sample by this test?
questions.solution:
Test Barberios - detects the presence of spermine, one of the components of prostate-derived semen.

On a glass slide one drop of the stain extract is applied and covered with a cover slip. After that, it is charged with a drop of saturated picric acid aqueous solution (1 g picric acid in 30 ml of distilled water) and given time to uniformly diffuse.
Look for needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals, which indicate the presence of semen, under the 100 objective of a microscope.

Memorizing Trick: -
BarberioS- Spermine 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 494.

questions.text:
Identify the laws governing insanity from the available options.
(i) Curren’s
(ii) Durham
(iii) Ashby
(iv) Murphy
questions.solution:
Durham’s rule—Acts that are the “products” of mental disease or defect excuse criminal liability.
Curren’s rule—It states that an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirement of law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
Both are not used currently in India.

Memorizing Trick:- Criminal Responsibility- Insane CAN Defend 
Insane- Irresistable impulse test
C- Curren's rule 
A- American Law Institute
N- McNaughten's rule 
Defend- Durham rule

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 494.

questions.text: Whose permission is needed for a medically assisted termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Wife

The criteria for consent to be taken in MTP is 
  • Minimum age – 18 years
  • If minor – guardian consent
  • Husband’s consent not needed

According to MTP amendment act 2021
  1. Indications
    • Therapeutic – risk to mother’s life 
    • Eugenic – any risk of severe physical deformity to the foetus 
    • Social – contraceptive failure
    • Humanitarian – pregnancy due to rape
  2. MTP act with respect to duration of pregnancy 
    • <20 weeks – all cases
    • >20 weeks – No MTP except in cases of 
      • Rape
      • Minor
      • Foetal anomalies
      • Mentally ill 
    • >24 weeks – substantial foetal anomalies (permission from medical board needed)
  3. Who can do MTP
    • Registered medical practitioner with diploma/degree in Obg 
    • 1 year experience in Obg 
    • Assisted 25 cases of MTP (5 should be done independently)
  4. Maintenance of records for 5 years 
Reference: Pai SN, Chandra KS. Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act of India: Treading the Path between Practical and Ethical Reproductive Justice. Indian J Community Med. 2023 Jul-Aug;48(4):510-513. doi: 10.4103/ijcm.ijcm_540_22. Epub 2023 Jul 14. PMID: 37662131; PMCID: PMC10470576.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to identify old and dried seminal fluid on an undergarment?
questions.solution:
The Barberio test is a forensic test used to detect old and dried seminal stains on clothing or undergarments.

Key points:

  • Barberio test:

    • Detects acid phosphatase activity in dried semen stains.

    • Useful when semen is old or partially degraded.

  • Other tests:

    • Precipitin test: Differentiates human vs animal blood.

    • Takayama & Teichmann tests: Detect hemoglobin in blood stains.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother and a lady police sub-inspector, presents with a reported history of sexual violence 2 days prior. What should the registered medical practitioner do next?
questions.solution:
The registered medical practitioner should first take a detailed history and obtain informed consent for the examination. If consent is refused, the refusal must be documented after explaining the potential consequences. Following consent, the practitioner should collect specimens, preserve clothing, and document injuries and examination findings. Medical treatment and pregnancy testing for victims of sexual assault must be provided free of charge, and the police should be notified as required by Section 357C of the CrPC.

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 defines individuals under 18 years of age as children and offers protection from sexual abuse. The Act outlines various forms of sexual offenses, including:

Sexual Harassment: This occurs when a person, with sexual intent, engages in any act with sexual connotations, makes a child display their body, or shows pornographic material to a child.

Sexual Assault: Involves any act with sexual intent that entails physical contact without penetration.

Aggravated Sexual Assault: Similar to sexual assault but includes additional criteria defined as “aggravated.”

Penetrative Sexual Assault: Involves an act with sexual intent that includes physical penetration.

Aggravated Penetrative Sexual Assault: Similar to penetrative sexual assault but includes additional “aggravated” criteria.


Aggravated offenses involve situations such as:

Committed by a person in a position of trust or authority, such as police officers, security forces, relatives, or doctors.

Occurring during communal violence.

Involving mentally or physically disabled individuals.

Gang sexual assault.

Utilizing deadly weapons.

Causing grievous harm.


The Act prescribes severe penalties, including life imprisonment and fines, based on the severity of the offense. Section 21(1) of the POCSO Act, 2012 mandates the reporting of child sexual abuse cases to law enforcement authorities by everyone, including parents, doctors, and school personnel. Failing to report suspected child abuse is an offense under the Act.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 35th edition, Page no 330,331 .

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What ts this called?
questions.solution:
Satyriasis is the term describing a male's excessive desire for sexual activity.

Don Juanism is another name for Satyriasis. Some men use sex as a way to cover up their intense inferiority complexes. By engaging in obsessive sexual interaction with women, some people suppress their unconscious gay inclinations. After sex, many of them lose interest in the woman.

Other choices

Nymphomania: A female's excessive desire for sexual activity

Frotteurism: Getting sex by rubbing or touching someone who isn't giving their consent.

Masochism: The propensity to find sexual pleasure in one's own suffering or embarrassment.

Note: Don Juanism is a symbol of male hypersexuality.

questions.text: Which of the following is an abnormal method used for criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
An abortion stick is an abnormal and unsafe method used in criminal abortions. It involves inserting a stick or similar object into the uterus to induce abortion. This method is usually performed by untrained individuals in non-medical settings and can lead to serious complications such as uterine perforation, sepsis, hemorrhage, or even death.

The other options — vacuum aspiration, mifepristone, and dilatation and curettage — are legal and medically recognized methods of abortion when performed by qualified professionals in appropriate settings.


Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 404

questions.text: What is the upper limit of Medical Termination of Pregnancy , according to the MTP act?
questions.solution:
According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, the gestational limit for abortion is:

  • Up to 20 weeks: Permitted with the opinion of one registered medical practitioner (RMP).

  • 20 to 24 weeks: Permitted for certain categories of women (such as rape survivors, minors, differently-abled women, etc.) with the opinion of two RMPs.

  • Beyond 24 weeks: Allowed only in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities with approval from a State-level medical board.

    Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act – Updated Upper Limits

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021 was enacted to expand access to safe abortion services and address the reproductive rights of women more comprehensively.

      1. Up to 20 Weeks – Permitted for All Women

  • Abortion is allowed up to 20 weeks of gestation.

  • Requires the opinion of one registered medical practitioner (RMP).

  • No specific category or reason required — general grounds like contraceptive failure, socio-economic issues, or unwanted pregnancy are acceptable.

    2. 20 to 24 Weeks – Permitted for Specific Categories of Women

For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, abortion is permitted only for certain categories, including:

  • Survivors of sexual assault or rape

  • Minors

  • Women with physical or mental disabilities

  • Women whose marital status has changed during the pregnancy (e.g., divorce or widowhood)

  • Women with pregnancy resulting from contraceptive failure (extended to even unmarried women under this amendment)

  • Women carrying fetal anomalies detected late in pregnancy

In these cases:

  • Abortion must be approved by two registered medical practitioners.

    3. Beyond 24 Weeks – Permitted Only in Cases of Fetal Abnormalities

  • If the pregnancy is beyond 24 weeks, termination is not routinely allowed.

  • However, it can be permitted only if:

    • There is a substantial risk of fetal abnormalities that are incompatible with life or would lead to serious physical or mental handicap.

  • Must be approved by a State-level Medical Board, which typically includes:

    • A gynecologist

    • A pediatrician

    • A radiologist/sonologist

    • Other specialists as designated by the state


Reference:Review of forensic medicine and toxicology including clinical and pathologic aspects page 35,349,351

questions.text:
A young patient who had a history of using drugs came into the emergency room. His respiration rate was 30 breaths per minute, and his pulse was 130.
His urea level was 100 mg/dL, and a blood gas study suggested metabolic acidosis. His creatinine level was 4 mg/dL. Crystals of calcium oxalate were found
in the urine.After being treated with intravenous fluids, gastric lavage, sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methylpyrazole, his symptoms significantly
improved. What was the chemical that he probably consumed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Ethylene glycol.

Metabolic acidosis along with increased urea and creatinine levels along with calcium oxalate stones is suggestive of Renal failure due to glyoxylic acid. Glyoxylic acid is a metabolite of ethylene glycol. The term “toxic alcohols” is a collective term that includes methanol, ethylene glycol, and isopropyl alcohol.

Like ethanol and methanol, metabolism of ethylene glycol begins with gastric mucosal alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase in liver.

Ethylene glycol is metabolised to glycolic acid which is the reason for Metabolic acidosis.

Glycolic acid is metabolised to Glyoxylic acid which is a precursor for oxalic acid, the nephrotoxic metabolite causing Renal failure.

Treatment – Fomepizole or Ethanol to prevent conversion of non toxic substances into toxic metabolites.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 583.

questions.text: Boiled lobster syndrome is evident in poisoning of:
questions.solution:
* Boric acid poisoning:
-Rarely fatal in adults because of the large amount needed for serious toxicity. 
-Non-specific gastrointestinal symptoms make up the first stage of poisoning.
-The 'boiled lobster' rash, an intense generalized erythroderma, manifests shortly thereafter, with extensive desquamation within 1-2 days.
-Serious effects of borate poisoning include cardiovascular collapse, seizures, and renal failure.
-The only potential therapy is dialysis or exchange transfusion which has been anecdotally effective.
-The main symptoms of boric add poisoning are blue­ green vomit, diarrhea, and a bright red rash on the skin.

Reference: Schillinger BM, Berstein M, Goldberg LA, Shalita AR. Boric acid poisoning. J Am Acad Dermatol. 1982 Nov;7(5):667-73. doi: 10.1016/s0190-9622(82)70149-5. PMID: 6216273.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning snake bites is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 4 Neostigmine has a role in krait bite

Neostigmine and atropine are only effective in cobra bites (neurotoxic poisons).

If there are signs of neuro paralysis, give 1.5 mg neostigmine for adults i.m. with 0.6 mg atropine i.v. to counteract the muscarinic effects of neostigmine. It is repeated twice at ten minutes interval. In cases of presynaptic envenoming such as kraits or Russell's viper a positive response does not occur. Before every injection, half mg. atropine should be given to block muscarinic side effects.

* Families of poisonous snakes:
  • Elapidae (king cobra, common cobra, common krait): Neurotoxic 
  • Viperidae (Russel viper, Saw Scaled viper, Humped pit viper): Hemotoxic 
  • Hydrophinae (Sea snakes): Myotoxic 
* Management of snakebite is as follows:
  • First aid: Carry No RIGHT
    • Carry- do not allow victim to walk
    • No- No tourniquet, No sucking, No electrotherapy, No incison, No pressure immobilisation
    • R- Reassurance (Most bites are by non-venomous snakes)
    • I- Immobilise the patient
    • GH- Get to Hospital immediately
    • T- tell doctor about any specific symptom noticed during shifting to hospital
* Pressure immobilization is for elapid bite when patient id >1 hour from medical care
  • ASV given if signs of poisoning seen (effective against 4 snakes – Common cobra, krait, saw scaled viper, Russel viper)
  • IV Neostigmine and Atropine given for neuroparalysis.
  • Wound debridement
  • Dialysis
  • FFP

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: Regarding the displayed image, all of the following claims are true except one:
questions.solution:
The image shows Deadly Nightshade or Atropa Belladonna
The berries of the belladonna plant (Atropa belladonna), from which atropine is derived, are sweet, despite being highly toxic. Hence options 4 is false.

Other options 

  • Causes blindness due to mydriasis (Option 1) – True
    Atropine blocks muscarinic receptors, leading to pupil dilation (mydriasis) and cycloplegia, which can cause temporary blurred vision and photophobia. In severe poisoning, this can contribute to functional blindness.

  • Contains atropine (Option 2) – True
    Atropa belladonna is a major natural source of atropine, which inhibits muscarinic receptors, leading to effects like tachycardia, dry mouth, urinary retention, and hallucinations.

  • Physostigmine is the antidote (Option 3) – True
    Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is used to counteract the anticholinergic toxicity by increasing acetylcholine levels and reversing central and peripheral effects of atropine poisoning.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: A 10 years old boy presented to the Emergency department with vomiting. Parents said that he had consumed 15 tablets of ferrous sulphate. Which drug should be used in such a patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is  suggestive of iron toxicity due to consumption of FeSO4 talets.
 
  • It is managed by administration of an iron chelator which among the given options is Option 3-Desferrioxamine.
 

Iron toxicity occurs when there is excessive iron in the body, leading to oxidative damage and cellular injury. It can be acute (from overdose) or chronic (from conditions like hemochromatosis).

Causes:

  • Acute: Accidental ingestion (common in children) or intentional overdose.
  • Chronic: Repeated blood transfusions, hereditary hemochromatosis, or excessive dietary supplementation.
Clinical phases of Acute toxicity:
 
  1. Gastrointestinal Stage (0–6 hours): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and hematemesis. Severe cases may show hypovolemic shock.
  2. Latent Phase (6–24 hours): Temporary resolution of symptoms, potentially masking ongoing systemic damage.
  3. Shock/Metabolic Stage (6–72 hours): Multiorgan failure, acidosis, hypotension, liver injury, coagulopathy, and hypoglycemia.
  4. Hepatic Stage (2–5 days): Fulminant liver failure, coagulopathy, and encephalopathy.
  5. Recovery Stage (2–4 weeks): Resolution with potential long-term complications like strictures in the gastrointestinal tract.
Mechanism: 

Excess iron generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing oxidative stress and damage to cellular structures, particularly in the liver, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnosis

  • Elevated serum iron levels (>300–500 µg/dL).
  • Increased anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Radiographic imaging may show radiopaque iron tablets in the stomach.
  • Evidence of liver dysfunction (elevated ALT/AST).
Management:
  1. Decontamination:
    • Gastric lavage (if ingestion is recent).
    • Whole bowel irrigation for significant ingestion.
  2. Supportive Care:
    • IV fluids, correction of metabolic acidosis, and management of shock.
  3. Chelation Therapy:
    • Deferoxamine: Binds free iron and facilitates its excretion in urine.
  4. Severe Cases:
    • Consider dialysis for iron chelate removal if deferoxamine fails.
    • Monitor for liver and cardiac complications.
Prognosis
  • Prompt treatment improves outcomes.
  • Delayed care or severe cases may lead to death or permanent organ damage.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 548.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2343, 2588, 2847, 3236.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia and joint pains. He is working in a pain factory since last 20 years. Blood test revealed anemia. Which enzyme is affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning and the enzyme affected in this case is option 4- aminolevulinic acid dehydratase or ALA dehydratase. 

The other key enzyme of heme metabolism pathway inhibited by lead is ferrochelatase. 
 

The patient's symptoms (fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia, joint pains) along with anemia and long-term exposure in a paint factory suggest lead poisoning. Lead poisoning inhibits key enzymes involved in the heme synthesis pathway, particularly:

  1. ALA dehydratase (delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase):
    • Lead directly inhibits this enzyme, leading to the accumulation of ALA (delta-aminolevulinic acid) in the blood and urine.
    • This contributes to anemia and neurological symptoms.
  2. Ferrochelatase (not listed as an option):
    • Lead also inhibits ferrochelatase, causing the accumulation of protoporphyrin in red blood cells.
Other options: 
 
  1. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase: Associated with acute intermittent porphyria, not lead poisoning.
  2. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: Deficiency causes congenital erythropoietic porphyria, unrelated to lead exposure.
  3. ALA synthase: This enzyme is regulated by heme levels but is not directly inhibited by lead.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropine is derived from Atropa Belladona which is a Deliriant.
Examples of cardiac poisons—
  • Digitalis
  • Oleander
  • Nicotine
  • Aconite.
 
  1. Aconite - A highly toxic plant that acts as a cardiac poison by altering the sodium channels, leading to arrhythmias.
  2. Atropa Belladonna - While it contains alkaloids like atropine that affect the autonomic nervous system (causing anticholinergic symptoms like tachycardia), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison.
  3. Cerebra Thevetia - Known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that can cause severe cardiotoxicity, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
  4. Digitalis purpurea - Contains cardiac glycosides (e.g., digoxin), which are classic cardiac poisons that can lead to arrhythmias at toxic doses.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 598-600.

questions.text: A Scorpion Sting case comes to casualty with features of pain, hypotension and pulmonary edema. Antidote of choice in such case is
questions.solution:
• Antidote of choice for scorpion sting is scorpion anti venom but Prazosin is given initially.
  • Prazosin, a postsynaptic alpha-1 blocker, counteracts the effects of excessive catecholamines and arrests the development of severe systemic features.
  • Scorpion antivenom directly neutralizes the venom, addressing the root cause of systemic symptoms like pain, hypotension, and pulmonary edema caused by the scorpion sting.
  • It is the definitive treatment when available, as it halts the progression of envenomation.

Other options:
 
  • Prazosin (1): A supportive treatment that counteracts the effects of excessive catecholamines (such as vasoconstriction and pulmonary edema), but it is not a direct antidote.
  • Furosemide (2): A diuretic, generally avoided in scorpion envenomation as it can exacerbate hypovolemia and worsen hypotension.
  • Dopamine (4): May be used to support blood pressure in cases of severe hypotension, but it does not counteract the venom's effects and is not the antidote.

In severe systemic scorpion envenomation, Scorpion antivenom is the antidote of choice, with prazosin playing a key supportive role in symptomatic management.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 566.

questions.text:
Symptoms seen in chronic arsenic poisoning are? 
(i) Aldrich Mee's line on nails 
(ii) Raindrop pigmentation 
(iii) Mixed Neuropathy 
(iv) Luminescent vomit 
(v) Bone marrow depression
questions.solution:
• Luminescent Vomit is not seen in Chronic arsenic poisoning - Its seen in phosphorus poisoning - rest all the features mentioned in the question are seen. 

The symptoms seen in chronic arsenic poisoning may include:

(i) Aldrich Mee's line on nails - This is a white line that appears on the nails and is caused by arsenic-induced damage to the nail bed.

(ii) Raindrop pigmentation -  Dark, irregularly shaped spots on the skin.

(iii) Mixed Neuropathy - This is a type of nerve damage that can cause tingling, numbness, and weakness in the limbs.

(iv) Bone marrow depression - Chronic exposure to arsenic can lead to bone marrow depression, which can cause anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Other symptoms of chronic arsenic poisoning may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, headaches, confusion, and seizures.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 539,540 .

questions.text: Treatment of acute arsenic poisoning is by?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol > EDTA 


The treatment of acute arsenic poisoning involves the use of chelating agents, which bind with arsenic and aid in its elimination from the body. The commonly used chelating agents for arsenic poisoning are:

  1. Dimercaprol (also known as British anti-lewisite or BAL): It is the first-line treatment for acute arsenic poisoning. Dimercaprol is administered by intramuscular injection and works by binding to arsenic and forming a complex that is excreted in the urine.

  2. Calcium EDTA (ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid): It is an alternative treatment for arsenic poisoning, particularly in cases where the use of dimercaprol is contraindicated or unavailable. Calcium EDTA works by binding to arsenic and other heavy metals and promoting their excretion in the urine.
     

    Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 517,518,539,540,544,556,592 .

questions.text: The manifestations of organophosphorus poisoning are all of the following except?
questions.solution:

The effects of organophosphates on the body include symptoms such as excessive salivation, lacrimation (tearing), urination, and defecation, which are collectively known as SLUD syndrome. Excessive cholinergic activity also causes bradycardia and bronchoconstriction. 
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 522,539,602,603,631 .

questions.solution:
• Constricted pupils (miosis) and bradycardia (slow heart rate) are not typical features of cocaine intoxication.
  • In fact, cocaine tends to cause pupil dilation (mydriasis) and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) as part of its stimulant effects on the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following poisoning will predominantly cause hypertension?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the poisoning that predominantly causes hypertension is Cocaine. 

Cocaine poisoning:
1. Cocaine is a potent stimulant and sympathomimetic that affects the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.
2. It acts by inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin, leading to their accumulation in the synaptic clefts.
3. The excess catecholamines, particularly norepinephrine, contribute to the increased sympathetic activity, vasoconstriction, and subsequent hypertension.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 522,539,602,603,631 .

choices.text: Respiratory symptoms like rhinorrhea, bronchorrhea and bronchospasm

questions.text: Most characteristic muscarinic symptom produced in organophosphorus poisoning?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the most characteristic muscarinic symptom produced in organophosphorus poisoning is 1. Respiratory symptoms like rhinorrhea, bronchorrhea, and bronchospasm.

Organophosphorus compounds inhibit the activity of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which leads to an accumulation of acetylcholine at the muscarinic receptors in the body. This excessive stimulation of muscarinic receptors results in a variety of symptoms known as the cholinergic toxidrome.

Respiratory symptoms such as rhinorrhea (runny nose), bronchorrhea (excessive mucus production in the bronchi), and bronchospasm (constriction of the airway) are particularly characteristic of muscarinic receptor stimulation seen in organophosphorus poisoning. These symptoms arise due to the activation of muscarinic receptors in the respiratory system.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 516,521,522,523 .

questions.text: A child went out to play and consumed some fruit. Later he presented with confusion, increased body temperature and urine retention. Select the correct option in this case for poisoning and antidote:
