The child has developed the following symptoms after consumption of an unknown fruit:

  • Increased body temperature: Hyperthermia
  • Urinary retention: Sympathetic activation/ Parasympathetic blockade
  • Confusion: Delirium
This likely represents Datura poisoning which may be caused due to the ingestion of the fruit of Datura fastuosa which are spherical and have sharp spines, thus called thorn apples.
The plant contains belladonna alkaloids such as hyoscine whose primary actions are anticholinergic for which the physiological antidote, physostigmine (reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) can be administered to this child along with other supportive measures.

* 8 D's: Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dilated pupils, dry; hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, drowsiness, death due to respiratory failure.

* Treatment:
(1) Emetics can be used.
(2) Washout the stomach repeatedly with a weak solution of tannic acid.
(3) Give activated charcoal and a cathartic.
(4) Wash-out the lower bowel frequently.
(5) Physostigmine one mg., i.v. or i.m., at hourly intervals. In many cases a single dose is sufficient.
(6) Pilocarpine nitrate, 5 mg. s.c. is useful, but it does not counteract action of datura on brain. It can be repeated after two hours.
(7) Morphine is to be avoided because of the danger of depressing the respiratory centre.
(8) Delirium can be controlled by bromides and short acting barbiturates, but ether or chloroform is more beneficial .
(9) Light diet, and free purgation should be carried on for 3 to 4 days to remove the seeds and to increase intestinal motility.
(10) Symptomatic.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 599.

questions.text: A patient presented with seizures, muscle tremors, backward arching of the spine after consuming some ayurvedic medicine. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A patient presents with convulsions, tremors, and opisthotonus, after consumption of herbal medicine due to a neurological poison, likely strychnine.

  • Mechanism of action: Antagonizes the inhibitory neurotransmitter glycine by blocking its postsynaptic uptake by brainstem and spinal cord receptors
  • Signs and symptoms:
    • Characteristic: ‘Conscious’ seizure (doesn’t cross blood brain barrier)
    • Convulsions: Initially clonic, eventually tonic, affecting all muscles at the same time
    • Risus sardonicus.
    • Opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, pleurothotonus
    • Muscles are completely relaxed in between convulsions
    • Cadaveric spasm

* Extra Edge:
 
  • The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles, so that the body typically arches in hyperextension (opisthotonos).
  • In supine position, the body is supported by the heels and head. The legs are adducted and extended, the arms are flexed over the chest or rigidly extended, and the hands are tightly clenched. The head is bent backwards, and the whole of the body becomes rigid, often assuming a bow-like form.
  • Sometimes, the spasm of the abdominal muscles may bend the body forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleorosthotonos).
  • Consciousness is not lost and the mind remains clear till death.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 613.

questions.text: During harvest season, a farmer was sleeping when he woke up due to a bite. He became drowsy and was brought to the hospital. The wound became red with pain and patient had profuse bleeding. Which of the following was the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The farmer has been bitten by an unidentified animal in the harvest season while sleeping. There is drowsiness with local signs of redness, pain, and continuous bleeding. This is likely to be hemotoxic snake bite envenomation like vipers (ophiotoxaemia).

Viperine bites are characterized by:
  • Severe pain within 8 minutes
  • Onset of swelling within 15 minutes
  • Blood-staining discharge from the wound, with persistent bleeding
  • Blisters in 12 hours in and around the bite site, progressing to involve the entire limb.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 563.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paresis, signs of UMN paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Beta oxalyl amino alanine

The scenario involves a poor farmer with successive crop failures, with signs of gait dysfunction and signs of UMN disease due to consumption of a toxin, this is likely to be a case of neurolathyrism.
It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/ Lathyrus sativus which contains Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOA) (toxic compound causing lathyrism)
The toxin present in lathyrus seeds has been identified as Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). It has been isolated in crystalline form and is water soluble; this property has been made use of in removing the toxin from the pulse by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soak water. Studies indicate that there is a blood-brain barrier to this toxin. In order to overcome this barrier, the pulse must be eaten in large amounts over a period of time for 2 months or more. Besides BOAA several other toxins have also been reported


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 701.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs was smuggled by the British to china?
questions.solution:
Opium was transported by Brtitsh to China in exchange for tea, silk and porcelain pots.

Reference: Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. "opium trade". Encyclopedia Britannica, 12 Nov. 2024, https://www.britannica.com/topic/opium-trade. Accessed 28 November 2024.

questions.text:
Match the following?
A. Datura 1 CVS
B. Nicotine 2 skin
C. Nux vomica 3 CNS
D. Nitric acid 4 Spinal cord
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is A-3 B-1 C-4 D-2
Datura- CNS
Nicotine- Cardiac muscle
Nux Vomica-Spinal Cord
Nitric acid- Skin

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page. No- 467.

questions.text: Which chelating agent is not used in heavy Metal Poisoning?
questions.solution:
Prallidoxime- PAM is used in OP poisoning and not in Heavy metal Poisoning.
It regenarates Active Acetylcholinesterase restoring Neuromuscular transmission.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No: 123.

questions.text: 23y old college student was brought to emergency . On examination he had pin point pupils. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is known to cause Mydriasis. Other drugs causing Mydriasis- Datura, Cyanide, Ether, Amphetamine, Pethidine.
Pinpoint pupil is seen in Opium poisoning, Morphine Poisoning, OP poisoning, Pontine Hemorrohage, Barbiturate poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 501.

choices.text: Look for dead snake brought by relatives
Use sling ot splint for right lower limb (pressure) immobilization

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital following a snake bite on the right foot. Two fang marks were observed on the dorsum of the foot along with minimal pain, swelling and bleeding at the site. The vitals were stable. Which of the following is the immediate step of management?
questions.solution:
For snake bites, especially elapid or neurotoxic bites, pressure immobilization is recommended to slow the systemic spread of venom through lymphatics.

Key steps in initial management:

  1. Immobilize the affected limb using a splint or sling; keep it below heart level if viper bite, pressure immobilization for elapid bite.

  2. Clean the wound with soap and water.

  3. Monitor vitals and for systemic envenomation (bleeding, neurotoxicity, hypotension).

  4. Polyvalent antivenom is indicated only if there are signs of systemic envenomation, not for minimal local symptoms.

  5. Do not attempt to catch the snake, as this is unsafe and not necessary for initial management.

questions.text: In which type of poisoning will there be increased secretion along with diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Among the listed options, ketamine poisoning (a dissociative anesthetic) can lead to increased secretions — particularly salivation and bronchial secretions — along with gastrointestinal hyperactivity such as diarrhea and vomiting.

Other options in brief:

  1. Crack (cocaine base): Causes sympathomimetic effects — dry mouth, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis; secretions are decreased, not increased.

  2. Cocaine: Similar sympathomimetic profile — no increased secretions or diarrhea, rather causes reduced GI motility.

  3. Cannabis: Leads to dry mouth, increased appetite, and slowed GI motility; secretions are decreased.

Hence, ketamine poisoning is associated with increased salivation, lacrimation, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 39 year old lady came with alleged history of rodenticide consumption. On examination patient had an irregular pulse, quadriparesis present. Lab investigations revealed severe hypokalemia. Name the active ingredient present in this poison
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario can be caused be Barium carbonate used in rat poison.
  • Barium carbonate is a local corrosive irritant that, after absorption, mainly acts on muscles including the heart muscles.
  • Initial symptoms include intense gastrointestinal distress, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Subsequently, muscle cramps and stiffness, pupil dilation, tongue and larynx paralysis, and vertigo occur.
  • Severe CNS manifestations include loss of reflexes and paralysis. Early impacts on the heart lead to elevated blood pressure, a slow and irregular pulse, and potential cardiac arrest in systole.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33rd Edition, Page No 548-549.

questions.text: All the following antidotes are used to treat Cyanide toxicity, Except?
questions.solution:
• Amyl Nitrite, Sodium nitrite and Sodium thiosulfate are used in treatment of cyanide toxicity.
  • Treatment aims at reversing the Cyanide-Cytochrome combination by providing nitrites which convert hemoglobin to Methhemoglobin.
  • The cyanide Kit contains- 21 Amyl nitrite pearls,two 10ml vials of 3% sodium nitrite, Two 50ml vials of sodium thiosulphate.
  • Glyceryl Trinitrite is used in management of Angina.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No 478-479.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy visited a village temple with his grandmother. On the way back, he cried inconsolably and was taken to the emergency department within 3 hours. He presented with altered sensorium, cold clammy extremities, increased salivation, and excessive sweating. Examination revealed pallor and priapism, with the following vital signs: BP 140/78 mmHg, HR 152/min, RR 36/min, and SpO2 96%. Which of the following treatments would be appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests a likely diagnosis of a scorpion bite, for which Prazosin can be used in management. Prazosin serves as a physiological antidote, counteracting the symptoms of adrenergic surge.

Scorpion venom is a potent autonomic stimulator that induces the release of large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenal glands and directly affects the myocardium. Typically, a scorpion sting presents with localized redness, burning pain that radiates along the involved dermatomes, localized swelling, and punctate hemorrhagic spots. Additional symptoms may include headache, profuse sweating, chest discomfort, paraesthesias, hypersalivation, cold extremities, and occasionally priapism. Hypertension often occurs early, while pulmonary edema and myocarditis may develop later.

Treatment includes:

Pain Management: Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids.

Sedation: Benzodiazepines for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, and muscle spasms.

Hypertension and Pulmonary Edema: Prazosin helps counteract the adrenergic surge associated with these effects.

Cardiogenic Shock: Antivenom, Prazosin, nitroglycerin, and dobutamine.

Cholinergic Effects: Atropine.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 556 .

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence
He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and has red conjunctiva. During the motor coordination assessment, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and speak normally. Which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where a person smells of alcohol but has normal motor coordination and no slurred speech, it suggests that the person has consumed alcohol but is not currently affected by it.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 579,580 .

questions.text: The Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease seen in toxicity of which of the following metal?
questions.solution:
Blackfoot disease results from chronic arsenic poisoning. In Taiwan, China, exposure to arsenic through drinking water has been linked to a severe vascular condition that causes gangrene, known as Blackfoot disease. This disease is characterized by platelet activation and increased blood coagulability in peripheral arteries and is commonly seen in regions with high arsenic levels.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 538-540,549 .

questions.text: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
Methanol toxicity often results from the ingestion of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase to formaldehyde and further by aldehyde dehydrogenase to formic acid, which are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinical Presentation: Symptoms of methanol toxicity include:

Headache
Vomiting
Abdominal pain
Confusion, delirium, and potentially coma
Visual disturbances: Damage to the optic nerve and retina can lead to blurred vision or blindness, which is a hallmark of methanol toxicity.
Metabolic acidosis is seen in arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis due to the accumulation of formic acid and other organic acids.

Treatment:

Gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate can be done if the patient presents within two hours of methanol ingestion to manage acidosis.
Ethanol infusion: Since ethanol competes with methanol for metabolism by alcohol dehydrogenase, it slows down the formation of toxic metabolites like formaldehyde and formic acid.
Fomepizole is the drug of choice and works by competitively inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing methanol from being metabolized into toxic substances.
Folate therapy: Administering calcium leucovorin (folate) enhances the breakdown of formic acid, reducing its levels in the blood.
Hemodialysis is employed in severe cases to remove methanol and its toxic metabolites from the bloodstream.
This approach aims to minimize methanol's toxic effects, particularly on vision and neurological function, while managing metabolic disturbances such as acidosis.

choices.text: Tingling and numbness in hands and feet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the stage of excitement in acute cocaine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is derived from the leaves of Erythroxylum coca and can be consumed through various methods, including snorting, intravenous injection, or smoking.

Stages of Cocaine Intoxication
Cocaine intoxication is characterized by two distinct phases:

1. Stage of Excitement:
Symptoms:
  • Dry mouth
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Increased heart rate (tachycardia)
  • Rapid breathing (tachypnea)
  • High blood pressure (hypertension)
  • Dilated pupils
  • Elevated body temperature
Psychological Effects:
Patients may experience feelings of euphoria and heightened excitement, along with restlessness and talkativeness. This phase can eventually lead to a more subdued state.

Neurological Symptoms:
Increased reflex responses
Tremors or seizures
Hallucinations
Tingling and numbness in the extremities

Note: Cocaine bugs, the sensation of insects crawling on or beneath the skin, are not typically present during the stage of excitement; they are more commonly reported by chronic users.

2. Stage of Depression:
Symptoms:
  • Weak respiration
  • Excessive sweating
  • Collapse
  • Convulsions
  • Risk of death
Effects of Chronic Cocaine Use:
Chronic users may experience cocaine bugs, a form of tactile hallucination characterized by the sensation of insects crawling on the skin or the feeling of sand grains beneath the skin. Additionally, chronic snorting can lead to ulceration of the nasal septum.

Treatment for Cocaine Intoxication:
For Oral Ingestion:
Perform gastric lavage using warm water mixed with potassium permanganate, charcoal, or tannic acid.

For Nasal or Throat Exposure:
Rinse the area with water.

For Intravenous Intoxication:
Apply a ligature above the injection site.
Antidote and Supportive Care:
The antidote for cocaine intoxication is inhalational amyl nitrite.
Additional supportive treatments include:
Managing seizures
Stabilizing the airway and circulation
Administering IV thiamine
Providing naloxone if needed.

questions.text: A girl was found dead in a close room containing a lit woodfire. Which of the following features is likely to be seen on their bodies?
questions.solution:
Cherry red discolouration is a hallmark of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. This occurs because COHb imparts a bright red colour, distinct from the darker hue associated with deoxygenated hemoglobin. Carbon monoxide is a byproduct of incomplete combustion of organic materials, such as wood. When inhaled, CO binds to • hemoglobin in the blood with an affinity approximately 240 times greater than that of oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb).
This reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, leading to tissue hypoxia.Ref- Synopsis of Forensic Medicine 28th edition Page 146

questions.text: Which of the following substances can typically be detected in the body during postmortem analysis, even if the person did not consume the substance shortly before death?
questions.solution:
After death, the body undergoes various biological processes, including putrefaction. During putrefaction, bacteria present in the gastrointestinal tract and other tissues can ferment carbohydrates, leading to the production of alcohol.
Therefore, Alcohol can normally be detected in visceral organs, even if not consumed right before death.Ref- Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 35th edition Page 97

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents to the
ER with complaints of muscle twitching and tremors. He gives a history of consuming crushed seeds from a plant.
Shortly after, he begins to experience refractory seizures and assumes a characteristic posture with arching of the back and rigid extension of the limbs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Strychnine poisoning occurs if a person ingests crushed seeds of Strychnos nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action. The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.
Patients present with: convulsions, Risus sardonicus, ophisthotonus, post-mortem caloricity is seen in cases where death is preceded by severe convulsions. Ref- Essential of Forensic Medicine 33rd edition Page 612

questions.text: In poisoning with which of the following agents can gastric lavage be carried out?
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage is the administration and evacuation of small volumes of liquid through an orogastric tube to remove toxic substances within the stomach.

Contraindications of Gastric lavage:
• Corrosive poisonings like sulphuric acid and kerosene (except carbolic acid).
• Convulsants/CNS stimulants (E.g. Strychnine)
• Comatose patients
• Volatile Hydrocarbons(E.g. gasoline)
• Upper GI pathology (E.g: esophageal varices)
• Hypothermic patient
• Bleeding diasthesis
• Advanced Pregnancy.

Reference Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition • Page no: 453 T

choices.text: 5 °C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/ cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many (minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis?

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5 °C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/ cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many (minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duke’s Minor Criteria present in this patient:

  1. Predisposing factor – IV drug use 

  2. Fever ≥38°C – 38.5°C 

  3. Vascular phenomenon – Roth spots (fundus spots) 

Thus, 3 minor criteria are satisfied.

This aligns with Duke’s criteria for infective endocarditis.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition 3859-3861

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The parents give a history of the child ingesting 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The child has acute iron (ferrous sulfate) poisoning, which can cause severe abdominal pain, vomiting, metabolic acidosis, and potentially shock.

  • Deferoxamine is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to bind free iron and enhance its excretion in urine.

Other options:

  • Dimercaprol: Used in arsenic, gold, or severe lead poisoning. Not effective for iron.

  • Penicillamine: Used in copper poisoning (Wilson’s disease) or heavy metals like lead/cadmium.

  • Activated charcoal: Ineffective for iron, as iron is not adsorbed well by charcoal.



Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 548

questions.text: Which of the following options describes the symptoms seen classically in a patient bitten by the snake shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Snake shown in the image is BANDED KRAIT. 
 


Incorrect Options:

  • Belongs to the Elapidae family (same as cobras)

  • Highly venomous

  • Identified by its alternating black and yellow bands along a slender body

    Venom Characteristics:

  • Neurotoxic: Acts on the neuromuscular junction, blocking acetylcholine release

  • Leads to progressive paralysis, starting with ptosis, ophthalmoplegia → respiratory muscle paralysis

  • Minimal local signs at the bite site (unlike viper bites)

    Clinical Features of Banded Krait Bite

    Timeframe Clinical Signs
    0–6 hours Often painless bite; minimal local swelling or redness
    6–24 hours Ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, blurred vision, facial muscle weakness
    24–48 hours Progressive flaccid paralysis, dysphagia, limb weakness, respiratory muscle paralysis
    Late signs Hypoxia, hypoventilation, respiratory arrest if untreated


    Management

    Supportive care

  • Airway and ventilation support: Most crucial

    • Intubation if respiratory distress or single breath count <15

  • Monitor oxygen saturation, vital capacity, ABG

    Antivenom

  • Polyvalent anti-snake venom (ASV) in India covers Bungarus spp.

     Anticholinesterase trial

  • Drugs like neostigmine + atropine may help (esp. in post-synaptic neurotoxicity)

  • Trial dose: Neostigmine 0.5 mg IV + Atropine 0.6 mg IV

  • Most effective early in the course before irreversible neuromuscular damage

  • Dosing: Typically 10–20 vials IV slowly, repeated if symptoms persist

  1. Non-poisonous, dry bite – Banded kraits are venomous

  2. Severe muscle necrosis, rhabdomyolysis – Seen in sea snakes and Russell’s viper

  3. Severe edema, necrosis and bleeding – Classic of vipers (e.g., Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper)


Reference:Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology 2nd edition page no 485

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The weed Parthenium hysterophorus is depicted in the picture.

An invasive weed that colonizes and poses risks to agriculture, the environment, and human health is Parthenium hysterophorus. Their rapid growth and colonization among other plants disrupts the ecology. The plant's constituent compounds, such as parthenin, hysterin, hymenin, and ambrosin, interfere with the growth of nearby crops.

Regarding the health risks, it has been demonstrated that the pollens and other plant parts can result in hay fever, asthma, bronchitis, contact dermatitis, and other allergies.

"Parthenium dermatitis" is the term for the contact dermatitis it causes.

Alternative medical systems employ parthenium for ailments like neuralgia, rheumatic pain, diarrhea, UTIs, dysentery, and malaria because it is thought to have certain health advantages.

Reference:Online Resource - https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/45573

questions.text: A young teenage boy presents to the emergency with a history of some drug abuse at a party a couple of hours ago. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, anxiety, and hyperactivity. On examination, there was tachycardia and hypertension. Which of the following substances might he have taken?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described — diaphoresis (sweating), headache, anxiety, hyperactivity, tachycardia, and hypertension — are classic signs of stimulant overdose, particularly cocaine.

Cocaine Toxicity – Key Features:

  • Stimulant of the central nervous system (CNS) and sympathetic nervous system

  • Blocks reuptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin

    Symptoms:

  • Psychological: Euphoria, anxiety, agitation, paranoia, hallucinations

  • Autonomic: Hyperthermia, diaphoresis, mydriasis (dilated pupils)

  • Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmias, chest pain

  • Neurological: Headache, seizures, stroke (in severe cases)

    Why other options are incorrect:

  1. Alcohol – Typically causes CNS depression, not hyperactivity; may cause hypotension, bradycardia, slurred speech.

  2. Cannabis – Causes euphoria, sedation, increased appetite; rarely causes severe hypertension or hyperactivity.

  3. Opioids – Cause CNS and respiratory depression, miosis (pinpoint pupils), hypotension, and bradycardia.

    Mnemonic to remember Cocaine Toxicity:

        COKE:

  • C: CNS stimulation (seizures, hyperactivity)

  • O: Overheating (hyperthermia)

  • K: Killer BP (hypertension)

  • E: Excited (anxious, agitated)


Reference:Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology Principles and practice 5th edition page no 498-412
